name: Aaron Provincial Park
text: This is an awesome well maintained park that has a little of everything. Noise can be a issue with the Highway 17 traffic. We usually come here to use the launch as Thunder Lake is a wonderful Lake Trout fishery. Good Walleye fishing can be had also.

name: Aaron Provincial Park
text: Good clean park.  Friendly staff.   A bit too close to the highway for me.  Too much traffic noise for my liking but still, a great park to stay at.

name: Aaron Provincial Park
text: Nice sites and facilities .way too close to the highway tho . The truck traffic is constant and the noise from it is overbearing.  If you're looking for a peaceful , quiet time this is not the place .Especially at night.

name: Aaron Provincial Park
text: This place is amazing. One of the best camp sites ive been too.

name: Aaron Provincial Park
text: Great place very clean codes to Nate and Shelley go job

name: Algonquin  Achray Campground
text:
Definitely stop in here and buy a souvenir, some firewood, or a well-earned popsicle after days out in the woods.

The folks working here are knowledgeable and kind.  We came in for directions to a jump-off point that we saw on the map.  The employees said it didn't exist... so we kinda blew them off and went searching.

The lady at the desk followed us out with a not-terrible map and schooled us on the surrounding woods.  Very happy she did.

name: Algonquin  Achray Campground
text: This is by far our favourite destination after 18 years of paddling together.  Short trip over to Stratton Lake and you have access to amazing campsites on the south shore.  Just around the corner is a perfect day trip to High falls.

name: Algonquin  Achray Campground
text: Amazing place. Number one all around. Nice staff. Not on lockdown can actually enjoy yourself there. The views are just spectacular. Must go to place. As well as take a hike down Barron Canyon

name: Algonquin  Achray Campground
text: Great campground. Just remember no cell service and no showers. But beautiful lake. And quiet.

name: Algonquin  Achray Campground
text: I LOVE the achray campground, we do the back country camping off of grand lake. The wardens are knowledgeable and very helpful!

name: Algonquin  Brent Campground
text:
A Must stop at when your portaging or camping they treat you like your family and not just a customer spending money.      Nothing quite like this back home at all.  If I could i would move up here.

Thank you for everything

name: Algonquin  Brent Campground
text: Friendly and informative. Will make sure yoh enjoy your stay!

name: Algonquin  Brent Campground
text: As much as I loved the campsites I stayed on over the past week, it couldnt have been better without the amazing Algonquin Outfitters and their very own Jake. What a great guy. Helped us by having numerous canoes and accessories for rent at very reasonable prices. All of which made for our trip to be memorable and wanting to return ASAP.

name: Algonquin  Brent Campground
text: Five stars seems so few when it comes to the customer service found at this store.  If I could, I'd give it 10 (or more).  You aren't just a customer here, you're a friend.  They really want to make your camping experience as amazing as possible.  I truly felt like they cared.  You may even be greeted by their two HUGE dogs who are really really friendly.  Even if you don't need anything, a pop-in to the store is a must for your camping experience.

name: Algonquin  Brent Campground
text: Nothing compares to a yearly canoe trip at Algoqnuin and with meeting these guys. Jake and Murry are always very welcoming and friendly, with a special touch of humor, always ready to give an advice or just to support a small talk ;) Highly recommemded place and my personal favourite for years and for years to come!!

name: Algonquin  Canisbay Lake Campground
text: We really enjoyed.  Lots of space on sites, not bare like some of the other Algonquin grounds.  We saw lots of wild life, moose near bathrooms, bear on trail, snakes, etc.  Construction was a little bit of a drag but perspective is important (it's only 5 minutes longer...)  Lots of things to do within bike, hike or short drive.

name: Algonquin  Canisbay Lake Campground
text: Great campground for families. Most campsites have decent privacy. Try camping!

name: Algonquin  Canisbay Lake Campground
text: Great site aside from the mud hole that could have been filled with the gravel that was piled up in the parking spot down the road.  We had a great time and would come back!

name: Algonquin  Canisbay Lake Campground
text: July/August and the lake is public swimming pool warm! Amazing water and views, and the hiking trails around Algonquin park are top notch if you just want to get out for some nice views and aren't a hardcore trekker, although they would enjoy it too I'm sure!

name: Algonquin  Canisbay Lake Campground
text: Campsites are very tiny (42) barely any room after parking two cars. Staff was helpful in telling us where not to go due to bears. Love being in Algonquin though.

name: Algonquin  Coon Lake Campground
text: Shallow Lake lots of fish lots of weeds but a very good time

name: Algonquin  Coon Lake Campground
text: Nice access to the lake, very organized. People should not park in front of landing at all. Loading or unloading ice fishing equipment. There is more than enough room in the parking lot

name: Algonquin  Coon Lake Campground
text: My oldest brother lives near there

name: Algonquin  Coon Lake Campground
text: Great boating and swimming lake

name: Algonquin  Coon Lake Campground
text: Gotta love coon lake. Decent size for recreation boating. Its too bad the state doesnt impose drivers license for boats. On multiple occasions we have been in dangerous situations due to yahoos following way too close to our rider in tow,  jet-skiers jumping our surf wave and almost hitting our surfer, or just being dumb and pull their tubers right in front of us as we are cruising in a straight line. Only gripe with the lake is the east boat landing. The one side is really uneven...

name: Algonquin  Kearney Lake Campground
text: Great car camping spot. Nice lake for quiet paddles and swimming. Access to the Algonquin Rail Trail.

name: Algonquin  Kearney Lake Campground
text: Good location. Good amount of showers, not all of them were working though. Beach is not the nicest but it was OK.

name: Algonquin  Kearney Lake Campground
text: Camp here every year. Decent sized sites. Nothing to far to the beach or comfort station. Outhouses need to be cleaned more often though. And the craters in the road.

name: Algonquin  Kearney Lake Campground
text:
Great campground overall. Has all the glamping amenities: showers and toilets and also has garbage, recycle and empty BBQ tank dropoff. The beach is pretty nice and calm and swim friendly. Amenities are relatively well taken care of but ducked a star, BC showers fill up early morning and they get grosser as the day goes by, I'm pretty certain they are cleaned mid dayish but it's worth knowing this as a camper. 
The campground is close to Opeopngo Canoe Rental store and many great hikes of various difficulties. Apparently you can order a canoe ahead of time and they drop it off at either pog Lake or Kearney Lake at 10am and pick it up the next day and everything is included in the rental price (and you don't have to carry your canoe).

name: Algonquin  Kearney Lake Campground
text: Hiked the lookout. Awesome trail for the family. View is spectacular.

name: Algonquin  Kiosk Campground
text: Very nice location for drive in camping. Lake is beautiful and there's a nice beach to go swimming. Most of the sites have a nice view of the lake, and the stars are beautiful at night on a clear day. Not sure how this campground is managed though as I was unable to find the camp host or anyone in charge of the place.

name: Algonquin  Kiosk Campground
text: Beautiful campsite. So nice we went back after staying (at the same site) 4 years ago! The lake is great and you can rent a canoe from the Algonquin shop and they drop it off the next day

name: Algonquin  Kiosk Campground
text:
Clean and peacefull camp site with flush toilets at some spots. There is no cell phone reception but they have a wired phone at the front desk. 
There is a canoe rental shop nearby which can deliver canoes and gear directly to the campsite. 
After heavy rainfall it is not recommended to swim in the lake (due to sime kind of bacteria)
Our visit was in mid september 2018 and we were almost alone on the campsite.
Some campgrounds near the river though were occupied by goose, which do leave some bird remains...

name: Algonquin  Kiosk Campground
text: Great entry point for a canoe trip in beautiful Algonquin Park. Located between the cities of Mattawa and North Bay. Very convenient entry point for people from outside the region.  There is also an reputable outfitter located nearby. Love it and will go back!

name: Algonquin  Kiosk Campground
text: More closer to wilderness. Excellent for canoeing and it is very well connected to isolated lakes inside the park. Don't canoe late in the evening as you might get lost or get trapped to wind. four stars is due to lack of  comfort station but this is very closer to back country camping experience

name: Algonquin  Lake of Two Rivers Campground
text: Fantastic place to camp. Very clean campsites and bathrooms.  Would definitely visit annually.  Camp staff are very polite. I called them to fix my electrical problem at the site and they were there within minutes.  Thank you for making my camping trip, one to remember.

name: Algonquin  Lake of Two Rivers Campground
text: Fantastic campground I been going since I can remember.  Nice size lots for trailers. Clean bathrooms can be very busy some families hog the showers . Beautiful beach walking trails and the store all within walking distance. Plus wild life we had bears in our site 8 out the 9 days we were there. Note to all keep your camp sites clean. We were the first site off the trail we ended up moving to a different site. Staff is amazing.  People love to speed along the roads city people . Also when driving to your sites if you can't see the number on the post for site you are going the wrong way.... Makes it difficult when pulling travel trailers.  We will be back until we can't.

name: Algonquin  Lake of Two Rivers Campground
text: An awesome place on this beautiful earth of ours - come and experience this most wonderful place for yourselves

name: Algonquin  Lake of Two Rivers Campground
text: Its a awesome place for camping. We all loved it. The first sign post to the entrance was of a bear scare. That was sufficient to excite us. Overall the place is great with nice Beach.

name: Algonquin  Lake of Two Rivers Campground
text: Lake of Two Rivers is a beautiful campground! My family and I went twice this year – once in June and another in September. The campground has such a unique feel as it is mainly filled with giant, towering pine trees. The campsites, for the most part, are very large however are not very private due to the tall pine trees dominating the area (with some exception). The beach is small, but the campground itself is close to a multitude of other beaches, landscapes, and adventures. There are many places to rent boats close by. This campground is home to the Lake of Two Rivers Store as well which is filled with many souvenirs, a small grocery section, and any other things you may have forgot to pack with you! There’s even a cafe which serves breakfast, lunch, dinner, and carries Kawartha ice cream. Lots of wildlife – this year we saw a moose, a mama bear with four cubs (which is a rarity), bull frogs, red squirrels, fed chipmunks and even somehow managed to gain the trust of two blue jays and hand fed them! Already can’t wait to go back.

name: Algonquin  Mew Lake Campground
text: Love this place for winter camping. Their host system is great and can be a life saver. The staff are all very friend and easy to talk to. Lots to see and do here. The hockey rink makes for fun day time game. There is a fair amount of wildlife to see here as well from turkeys, martens, otters and moose! Very kid friendly as well

name: Algonquin  Mew Lake Campground
text:
Went Dec 18-21 and the park was beautiful. Went with a bunch of friends to hike and photo shoot and we were more than impressed with the trails. There was a good number of them too. A few paths were closed but we still had a great time.
Bonus: wildlife are not afraid to interact with you.

name: Algonquin  Mew Lake Campground
text: We love Mew Lake in the winter.  Thank you to Harvey Cornell for always going that extra mile to make the park such a wonderful place to be.  And thanks for always making that rink so amazing for the Hockey players and skaters.

name: Algonquin  Mew Lake Campground
text: Great in all seasons, winter time is a must to experience the ice rink alongside the fire pit. Bring hot dogs and marshmallows for roasting along with skates.

name: Algonquin  Mew Lake Campground
text:
Awesome place! The campground is well maintained and clean. Flush toilets and showers make it an easy sell for those not really into the back country style camping. 
The beach was a nice soft sand bottom with nice clear water. For the bikers, the campground connects to the 16km bike trail and also has a nice bike path to the store/cafe. Staff was kind and helpful.

name: Algonquin  Pog Lake Campground
text: Beautiful location! Although no lockers for the food at the camp ground. Close to the Centennial Ridge trail (the lookout point is worth the hours on the trail).

name: Algonquin  Pog Lake Campground
text: I really enjoyed it here. We were with a group of friends and two dogs and we all had an awesome time. Our campsite was huge, the park had great amenities, a beautiful little lake and beach....it was a great way to spend a long weekend. We would go back for sure - even with the 3 hour drive.

name: Algonquin  Pog Lake Campground
text: Good place for car camping. Algonquin Park was beautiful and being right on the water at Pog lake just added to it! The sites are a little close and there is little to no privacy on the sites close to the lake. We were a few rows back at a site with more privacy/trees and the walk to the lake was only a few mins. Lots of kids!

name: Algonquin  Pog Lake Campground
text: This is my favorite campground in algonquin. I have seen moose and bear wandering around inside there campground. Washrooms are clean sites are generally good and the beach is nice. Of course if you plan on visiting on a long weekend in the summer the atmosphere will be a lot different. If you can tolerate the mosquitoes try visiting mid June during the week. You will feel like you have the park to yourself

name: Algonquin  Pog Lake Campground
text: My mom started camping in Algonquin, Two Rivers, back in the 60s with her family. In 1980, she started with her family. I have so many amazing memories here. When I was a kid, campground C had lots of seaweed, but that's been gone a while now. A bit cool this spring, but still fantastic spots. Clean facilities and great trails around

name: Algonquin  Rock Lake Campground
text: 35 years of Camping in Algonquin park and Rock Lake always brings me back. The lake, river to Whittefish and trails  Booths Rock and Old Rail Bike trail are exceptional. The Campground is best enjoyed from a lake front direct water access site in campground  B (no hydro). Site Privacy is minimal but the location and park staff are exceptional.

name: Algonquin  Rock Lake Campground
text: My favourite place to stay in Algonquin. Quiet and away from it all without the need to paddle or hike in. Campground B is much quieter than campground A. Most of the waterfront sites have direct access to the water and your own beach area. You cannot take your dogs on the main beach, however, if you have a waterfront site, you can take you dog in there.

name: Algonquin  Rock Lake Campground
text: Beautiful Algonquin campground. Friendly and helpful staff!

name: Algonquin  Rock Lake Campground
text: Lots of rules base on perception, it could have been better it they were more organize

name: Algonquin  Rock Lake Campground
text: Very good and clean campground with a friendly and helpful staff.

name: Algonquin  Tea Lake Campground
text: Nice and quiet campground and the park staff was extremely friendly

name: Algonquin  Tea Lake Campground
text: Fall colors are always best at Tea Lake Campground.

name: Algonquin  Tea Lake Campground
text: Site #43 was pretty good. The bugs are bad this year but that didn't take away from the spot. We'll be back.

name: Algonquin  Tea Lake Campground
text: Camp ground is close to beautiful lake and scenery but it is too close to the main road and you will hear cars passing.

name: Algonquin  Tea Lake Campground
text: Lovely colors at this time of the year

name: Algonquin  Whitefish Lake Campground
text: Beautiful setting. Friendly hosts. Add $3 for a 5 min shower, $6 for some firewood and a train that kills all the good this setting offers and I am thinking twice before another night. Bathrooms can be cleaner. The scenery is why you go there.

name: Algonquin  Whitefish Lake Campground
text: I went there for a evening walk. Enjoyed it. There were few others there. Some one was going kayaking. Since it was a short visit, attendant fid not charge me.

name: Algonquin  Whitefish Lake Campground
text: The worst place to stay. The train goes by every half to 45 min. And sounds like it is literally is coming thru the woods. NO sleeping at this campsite. The showers take 2 minutes to warm up and they are only 6 min. [Payed] showers.

name: Algonquin  Whitefish Lake Campground
text: Very beautiful view of Whitefish Lake. We camped overnight. Don't stay on the west side of the campground unless you readily sleep with ease through earthquakes, thunderstorms, tornadoes, and screaming toddlers...at the same time. The trains began at 11:00 p.m. and seemed to continue every half hour or so until 5:00 a.m. They seemed quieter on the east side of the park, but not by much. On the plus side, the camp hosts were amazing, very friendly, and super helpful (on their own, 5 Stars!!!). But the loud (85-95 decibel??) trains all night elevated above our campsite would alone be worth One Star no matter how great the scenery. Perhaps a day trip, but we likely won't be back to camp.

name: Algonquin  Whitefish Lake Campground
text: Played frizbee golf with family . Had a great time

name: Arrowhead Provincial Park
text: Cross country skiing was fun, $30 for day pass for two people plus $45 for two people to rent skis, poles and boots. Nice Visitor centre but was truly busy by 1pm. Wished the skating trail was open but we came early in the season. Worth a visit and hope to come back during the warm months!

name: Arrowhead Provincial Park
text:
Great winter cabins! Very cozy! Hiking relatively easy if you don't want to rent snowshoes or skis...but you can! As a winter adventure(Really can't speak to summer) this place is top notch. Quiet, clean and lots of activities and places to get warm. Friendly staff too!
We'll be back!

name: Arrowhead Provincial Park
text: Lovely park, worth exploring in the winter too... tons to do. Went in Sept last year and the bugs were surprisingly brutal for that time of year. Campsites aren't stacked on top of one another which is awesome. Usually a back country camper but this was a great place for car camping. Friendly staff, clean, quiet.

name: Arrowhead Provincial Park
text: love going here in the winter to ski. trails are great and well marked. new lodge building is very nice. Also skated on the ice skating trail that runs in the woods and it was good too but of course bumpy.

name: Arrowhead Provincial Park
text: Have skated on the track several times. Great place for family fun. So many things to do. New   Lodge is awesome.

name: Awenda Provincial Park
text:
Always pleased leaving a park in this beautiful country. The campsites where very large, with gorgeous, old, tall trees all around, and lots of greenery. The staff was friendly and the office/park store was clean. 
The staff where very helpful when my car battery died over night and had maintenance come very quickly to boost it! Very friendly gentlemen. 

The not rocky beaches are a bit of a walk away, from the parking lot making it a bit inconvenient to travel with little ones. But be reassured, it is qell worth the hike! 
And the hiking trail called beaver pond was disappointing with no pond, and barely any remains of beaver activity. It was a boardwalk which made it accessible.
The only downfall of the campground is with the large trees there was much open space in between causing the neighbours to be clearly see on all sides, not much privacy, but most of the camp sites are shaded. And the lack of a visitor Centre is disappointing.
Overall great park to build lasting memories!

name: Awenda Provincial Park
text: The drive to get there isn’t that long compared to other provincial parks.  It is a nice place to camp. Well maintained. Dog beach is very nice but small. If you have a dog and you come in late on a sunny day you will have a tough time to look for a spot at the dog beach. It can get crowded. The beach is great and water temperature is warmer than the other beaches. Trails are great. Campsites are huge, lots of trees.

name: Awenda Provincial Park
text: Definitely a place you should check out.  Beautiful beach!  Friendly staff when you register.  Easy to park.  Make sure you grab a map before you enter.  It can be a bit confusing if it's your first time.  Great for family & friends.  And wonderful place to bring your dog.  They'll love the water.  Thanks Awenda!  Can't wait to come back!

name: Awenda Provincial Park
text: This is a gorgeous provincial park, not too far from the city and a wonderful quiet getaway. The only draw back for me is that the beaches are mostly natural and so not that sandy, with the nicest ones being quite a walk (since you can’t park close-by). Otherwise, Awenda is lovely, staff are always helpful and the park is kept clean. Sites are well maintained and have enough trees around to offer decent privacy wherever you are. Limited cellphone reception but who needs that when you’re in the great outdoors!

name: Awenda Provincial Park
text: Lovely beach, gets lovelier the harder you work for it. Facilities are well maintained and the showers are fantastic. Park is very well kept. Even after four days of heavy rain, this park is a gem.

name: Balsam Lake Provincial Park
text: Went once and fell I love with the place! Great place for families! Lake is awesome for swimming and kayaking (rentals are available). Lots of trails for walking. Camping sites are decent with washrooms close by. Definitely would go again.

name: Balsam Lake Provincial Park
text: Wow, it's a very popular and beautiful spot. We just went to go for a walk there over Thanksgiving weekend and can't believe how many people are there camping. It looks like a great community and plenty seen to be planning to stay until Halloween as their sites are already decorated. They have some very private sites as well as some that are right beside each other so you can mingle with your neighbors. The beach is pretty big with nice sand and 3 different roped off areas that looks like it's for different agree groups (there's a very shallow small area which i presume is for toddlers. They rent paddle boats and canoes. At the far southern end there's a pathway to a 1 pump gas station convenience store which seems to have everything you need. The guy working there is super friendly.

name: Balsam Lake Provincial Park
text: Very nice camping spot. Cozy sites. The faucets in the men's washroom at the Poplar comfort station needs to be changed. It's wasting lots of water and not hygienic as you need to hold the knob as you wash one hand. They should be replaced with faucets that have a built-in motion sensor. Beach was very nice and sandy. Customer service was great. Staff were smiling and very nice.

name: Balsam Lake Provincial Park
text: Very clean water and not too crowded. There are covered picnic areas that can be used. One can also book the whole picnic shed if there is a large group. There is also a volleyball net with sand underneath the feet. Space is also available for camping if one wants to camp overnight.

name: Balsam Lake Provincial Park
text:
Favourite provincial park to camp in so far. The beach surprised us, actually a sandy beach! Lake water was warm once you got in and you could go probably 50 meters before the sand turned to seaweed. 

At the campsites we chose power without water. Washrooms were right next to us and all of our neighbours were cool. It's quiet and not far from two or three cute towns.

name: Bass Lake Provincial Park
text: Amazing, picturesque and tranquil place to spend some quality time. This place definitely warrants a visit during the early and mid fall time frame. The foliage and colors hugging along the shoreline of the lake is really worth the trip. The park is equipped with adequate parking, has a small children's play ground, has picnic tables and is a good place for a walk in the early mornings. Will definitely visit again.

name: Bass Lake Provincial Park
text: I always come here with my church for our annual beach trip. The park is always well kept and clean. Renting the side houses are always easy to do. The beach is lovely to swim in. And the walking trail is beautiful to take a stroll.

name: Bass Lake Provincial Park
text: The have plenty ample campsites...they have large and smaller sites....even the smaller sites, have plenty of room.  The showers & bathroom facilities are pretty clean. Really well laid out. And really friendly staff. Would definitely recommend Bass Lake to anyone.

name: Bass Lake Provincial Park
text: It is a great park if you are wanting to get some camping in but don’t want to drive for hours. They have a beach, kayak and canoe rentals, playground and a park store. Facilities and sites are maintained. If you forget something Orillia is a very short drive. Our fire wood was dry which is rare with the parks and the ice was cheaper then the grocery store I got it from. I always hit this place once or twice a year for a quick camp weekend.

name: Bass Lake Provincial Park
text:
Lovely park. 
Lots of walking. 
The park store was amazingly reasonably priced.
Free borrowing of fishing gear...no deposit.
Bathrooms are well kept. 
Friendly crowd. Can't wait to go back. 
Ten minutes away from Orillia

name: Batchawana Bay Provincial Park
text: Camping is nice here.  Lots of good sites with nice views.  The water is relatively warm considering it is in lake Superior. There are good hiking trails in the area including near pancake bay a bit down the road and especially at Lake Superior park which is an hour down the road.  Make sure to stock up on food etc in Sault Ste Marie because there isn't much in the way of groceries near here except some way over priced camp stores near the park with limited stocks.

name: Batchawana Bay Provincial Park
text: Been around a long time. Very well established Provincial Park. Right on the TransCanada Hwy 17. Gorgeous sand beach!  Often hard to get in, as it is so popular!

name: Batchawana Bay Provincial Park
text: Good deals with the retirement sale. A shame this place is closing. If I had the $ I would buy it because it can generate income in the North

name: Batchawana Bay Provincial Park
text: Park is closed for the season when I visited in mid October 2018. However, the colorful Fall leaves are still visible along the shoreline.

name: Batchawana Bay Provincial Park
text: The place here was a place I'd visit again, friendly, and Madee feel like home.

name: Blue Lake Provincial Park
text:
Camping at Blue Lake is a wonderful summer tradition for my family - we've been coming here for 15 years!  Lovely beach, hiking trails to suit every fitness level including a trail that is wheelchair accessible, great interpretive centre and family-friendly activities... this really is an outdoor destination with something for every nature lover! 

Vermilion Bay is a short drive away and offers a well-stocked grocery store, restaurants and a nice little bakery with the best coffee and sticky buns! 

You won't be disappointed if Blue Lake is a camping destination!

name: Blue Lake Provincial Park
text:
Massive campsite with lots of amenities (Hikes, beach, interpretive centre, showers). It was a bit too much of a party campsite (noisy, drunks, etc) and very expensive for my tastes but it was also like a friendly little town during the day.

And no floodlights! Nice place overall. Bring earplugs.

name: Blue Lake Provincial Park
text: Always a beautiful place go. Especially if the weather is good. Lots of trails to explore and the lake is as cold as can be. Have been going for the past 16 years.

name: Blue Lake Provincial Park
text: Small but packed with beautiful campground, forest and hiking trails for its size. Beautiful clear water.. One of our favourite places in the region.

name: Blue Lake Provincial Park
text: Great sites, beautiful & cold, clear lake for swimming. There are many nice hiking trails for every effort level and ripe blueberries growing along one of them! The interpretive center was a quiet building to escape the heat and the lady on staff was very knowledgable about the local flora and fauna.

name: Bon Echo Provincial Park
text: This place holds a special spot in my heart. The landscape is so compelling.   I love walking the trails and observing nature this place makes taking great photos easy.  The trail along the rock is a must for those who are ready for a more challenging walk.  Take a moment as well to check out the interpretive center, besides learning about the park they can let you know if anything else interesting has been planned.  Pack a lunch, hang out at the beach, they even have a beach area for the dogs to cool off too.  It's a beautiful destination worth the price of admission.

name: Bon Echo Provincial Park
text: bon echo offers quiet, well-appointed camping sites ideal for families.  lovely sandy soil floors - perfect for tent pegs.  water and washrooms nearby, with a really nice central washroom and shower facility a few minutes away.  the beaches are excellent and the cliffs spectacular...with opportunities for cliff jumping!  highly recommended.

name: Bon Echo Provincial Park
text:
I love Bon Echo! I've visited several times and it really is one of my favorites. It's a pretty big park and you can go on a kayak or canoe to the little petroglyphs along the water. There aren't a lot of mosquitoes along the water, but there are along the campsites especially the one that's a drive out far away from the main park. Bring bug spray! There are 2 beaches that are very nice, but the water is cold, but it's still warmer than other Canadian lakes. 

The hike across at the rock wall is pretty fun to do and I'd recommend it along with the hike around the lake. I've also done the owl walk here and it was pretty informative. I later heard a spooky noise but I knew which owl it was!

name: Bon Echo Provincial Park
text:
Incredible. Magic. Amazing. How do you write a review about the provincial park where you got engaged?! My fiance popped the question at the top of the Mazinaw Rock, overlooking the lake and all of the trees - it was the most magical experience ever. They have canoe and kayak rental here to get across the lake for hiking.

I camped here once as a little girl and the view and the experience never left me. Coming back here as an adult was truly something special. My favorite provincial park in all of Ontario - check it out!

name: Bon Echo Provincial Park
text: Went there on a Sunday Monday early September and it was surprisingly busy but we managed to get a site on the walk trail to your site. Surprising awesome spot pic 1. The pictographs on the rock were surprisingly small as I’ve seen others on Lake Superior much larger but still very cool and comparing them to the others I’ve seen was great. The guides are fantastic and the park is really really well kept

name: Bonnechere Provincial Park
text:
Nice place

Those of us who love short stories know the magic behind a well-told tale. There are times when you just need a complete story with a beginning, a middle, and an end. And you need it fast.

Well, we’ve got some great news:A lot of incredible short stories are actually available online, and you can read them for free right now. It’s the perfect way to spend a lunch break, the moments while dinner is in the oven, or your last few minutes before bedtime. Without further ado, here’s our list of great short stories you can read for free right now. The list features a blend of works from contemporary authors, as well as short stories from your favorite classic authors.

Contemporary Short Stories

These stories are by contemporary authors.If you’ve never read these authors before, their free short stories will give you a taste of their style before you commit to one of their longer works. There’s something for everyone, with stories in genres ranging from sci-fi to historical fiction to horror.

name: Bonnechere Provincial Park
text: One of the best parks in Ontario. The lake is crystal clear for swimming and some pretty great fishing too.

name: Bonnechere Provincial Park
text: This park is BEAUTIFUL!  Our site was very large, the staff was amazing, Round Lake a shallow beach which is great for families and it's also an accessible beach.  Highly recommend paddling down the Bonnechere River.  Rent or bring your own.

name: Bonnechere Provincial Park
text:
We are at camp site 6.
There is trail to the comfort station.
The only downside is that the electrical outlet is on the wrong side.  The wire goes right through the campsite.
Water is great, play area is great...camp store is adequate.

name: Bonnechere Provincial Park
text: Well taken care of park. The sites are spaced out nicely so you are not on top of each other. Would recommend getting to book one of the sites that are on the river. The beach is quite sandy all the way out. And the swimming area is large. They have boat rentals per hour and day. During the summer there are also weekend activities for children pour on by the park. 9/10 would go back.

name: Bronte Creek Provincial Park
text: Beautiful trails to hike! Great for beginners few hours before sunset you can encounter groups of deer at close view they have haunted house to discover as well small farm. Great for families with kids and or just couples. There is a timmies in front of the park.

name: Bronte Creek Provincial Park
text: Edit: The park is not worth if we just want to visit and enjoy the scenery as the entry fee is too expensive. I would suggest that the park facilities like golf,  animal farm may have a price but if we want to just go there and see the trees or if children want to play in the swing it should be free. Why is it that every time we come to see the trees we have to pay 17 dollars. Aren't we already pay so much of taxes for running these parks and public facilities?

name: Bronte Creek Provincial Park
text: I like the park for mountain biking. I mainly ride on the east side of the park (Oakville side) from the campground area. I am getting annoyed with the number of dogs who are running leash free but are not trained to do so properly. I always slow down when approaching people on foot but I still run into problems. Today I came across a Mother and son walking their Lab and German Shepard. I saw them in advance and turned down a parallel path to avoid them but the dogs cut through the bush and came at me snarling. I stopped the bike immediately and stayed still until the dogs turned back due to the calls of their owners (who did not apologize). This is one example but it happens regularly. Other people have very well behaved dogs who stay at the side of their owner or don’t even bother with me as I pass. If you can’t control your dog, keep it on the leash.

name: Bronte Creek Provincial Park
text: This is a nice little park with easy to do trails for everyone. Fall colours are nicely visible given the right timing. Great for a simple day trip from Toronto. There's plenty of parking and picnic spots as well and the trail maps they provide are very useful.

name: Bronte Creek Provincial Park
text: Lovely park with something for everyone. A little forested oasis in the city/suburbia. Day use area has a children’s barn and play areas, a farm and walking trails. Campground side also also an off leash area for dogs that we love.

name: Caliper Lake Provincial Park
text: Nice campground and very well cared for by the staff. They really take pride in keeping the campsite clean and comfortable for guests to stay at. Scott (the campground manager I believe) totally bailed us out after getting a flat tire from a nail we must have hit on the highway. Not only did he find a mechanic for us on Canada Day long weekend, but he went above and beyond to make sure our vehicle was safe to drive home. All around a great experience (and had a great time canoeing on the water!) Would definitely recommend!

name: Caliper Lake Provincial Park
text:
I just have to be honest, we didn’t really enjoy our stay here. However , we did come from camping on the west coast where things are a lot different. The water here is shallow and I don’t know if that’s why there is just so much algae ? It floats by and doesn’t look all that appealing to cool off in. Not only that but my son had a few leeches stuck to him which wasn’t a pleasant experience. There are TONS of bugs here black flies sand flies deer flies and mosquitoes which made it almost impossible to just sit down and relax at any point even with an armor of bug spray candles etc. Camping all across Canada we didn’t have this issue. Our tent in the morning looked like ants, spiders and flies took the home up as their own. Covered !!  The scenery is beautiful and the camp employee is AMAZING. He went above and beyond. It didn’t help that a lady next door to us let her dogs bark through the day uncontrollably.

The park experience we had is at no fault really of the park staff or campgrounds. We just prefer the lakes that look more clear and maybe a time with less bugs... I doubt there is any though.

name: Caliper Lake Provincial Park
text: Beautiful clear lake. The water smelled and tasted sweet. Good tree cover plus fire and ice delivery. Gorgeous spot.

name: Caliper Lake Provincial Park
text: Lovely non service lake side sites but not for those with a hard time walking on uneven surfaces. Electrical sites can be small and tight due to the big pines but sites fill up fast

name: Caliper Lake Provincial Park
text: Another beautiful provincial park. Well worth the journey

name: Charleston Lake Provincial Park
text: We had such a great time on the lake! The staff was polite, kind and a lot of fun!  We enjoyed the programs in the park. And, it wasn't too far to go into Kingston. We did the 1000 islands Dinner Cruise. We rarely go back to the same place, but we will be going back to Charleston Lake!!!!!

name: Charleston Lake Provincial Park
text: Tough review to write. As far as our campsite goes it was the worst of all the Provincial Parks we've been too. There is very little privacy. The next campsite is literally RIGHT beside you. The ground was full of gravel and roots from trees. Very few grassy sites. And the one we saw were very small and open with zero privacy. There were a few sites that were right beside the lake. But those were mostly electric sites for RVs. Now this park has excellent trails for hiking. We didn't even bother with our bicycles because the roads were too narrow and none of the trails were conducive to riding. Great views of the lake. Friendly staff.

name: Charleston Lake Provincial Park
text: Been coming here 35+ years, great during the summer but rediscovered it in the fall season. make sure you reserve very very early for premium sites. clean beaches, good trails, lots to explore.

name: Charleston Lake Provincial Park
text: Nice lake, beach was great to cool off in! Not much of a breeze during the heat wave though, made for warm camping trip. Don’t keep garbage out for too long, raccoons wont take long to find it. Common garbage/dumpster bins should be emptied more often to prevent raccoons from getting to overflow garbage. Bathrooms could be cleaner.

name: Charleston Lake Provincial Park
text: Love this place. We had a few roudy neighbours this year. The park staff did the best they could, but it made for a rather unpleasant experience. The  David Archibald show at the amphitheatre was great, as was the learn to fish clinic for the kids. If you go here, look at the activities that are planned. They are free and well worth it.

name: Chutes Provincial Park
text: Quiet little park. Some campsites backing on residential. Adequate spacing between sites.   Picturesque river but no real place to swim...only good wading for kids.  Off-leash fenced dog park near the water. Adjacent town has basic amenities.

name: Chutes Provincial Park
text: We only had an overnight stay at this park, but We loved it. Nice sites, clean bathrooms, good showers, friendly staff. The waterfalls are nice. The swimming area looks good as well although we weren't able to try it on our stay.  This is a nice quiet park.

name: Chutes Provincial Park
text: Beautiful woodsy park that was empty except for our camper, in September 2018.  Mind you, it was raining buckets. Sites were large with wooded verges visually separating the sites. My only downer was having to pay for electricity even though we didn't use any. And the train that loudly whistled by across the river

name: Chutes Provincial Park
text: been going to chutes for the last 30 years and always a great time

name: Chutes Provincial Park
text:
The water at this beach is warm and clean...ideal for little children.
There is a warning for older children who might wander off. Don't. Don't go down river from here. Can't swim there! It's very dangerous to follow this river too near the highway! The channel narrows and the speed of the rapids gets crazy and can be fatal to good swimmers. So, just stay upstream. Always explore upstream to see how safe it is. Don't go so far downstream that you can't get back! Enjoy the beach and the park hiking trails! They get really good reviews. People generally have only good things to say. This park's water comes from the city so it is treated and safe. There is a phone # listed and this park is open! Someone posted that it was closed. Not true.

name: Craigleith Provincial Park
text: What an amazing park. Don't know where to start staff was awesome. Bathrooms where so clean. Loved the swimming. The other campers where so friendly.  Definitely going back next season.

name: Craigleith Provincial Park
text: The best part about the park is access to the lake. It's beautiful and shallow. Lovely place for families. We were camping close to the highway and it was loud. If you can't get a spot right on the lake, don't go. Those spots are quieter.

name: Craigleith Provincial Park
text: I give the camp ground a 5, it's very nice.  Right on the water and beautiful.  Clean showers and baths. Sites are smaller than I expected but there is so much waterfront to explore it didn't matter to us. Went with my 2 kids. Had a site on the water,  wouldn't recommend having a site not on the water due to the high volume of traffic whizzing by. We loved it.  However your right on the highway too. So I give it a 3.  Unfortunately the traffic driving by is so loud you can't hear the water or a whole lot of anything else, sort of puts a black flag on your relaxing camping experience.  Hard to feel "away from it all" with a transport/dump truck rolling by every 45 seconds.  Bring ear plugs if you want a decent nights sleep.

name: Craigleith Provincial Park
text: Our site is right on the water. Amazing sound of the waves. Not a lot of privacy which we semi fixed with the set up of our trailer and truck. We are right in the middle of where the facilities are so we have the longest walk to the washrooms. Site 196.

name: Craigleith Provincial Park
text: My friends and I stayed 5 days here this past week and we loved it. Even though we were right by the highway we found it easy to tune out any noise coming from it. The beach was beautiful and we were able to watch some beautiful sunsets. While campsites are very close to each other, everyone we met was very friendly and kept to themselves. Definitely will come back if we can.

name: Darlington Provincial Park
text: We were pleasantly surprised to be able to book this campsite the same week. The park is well kept, washrooms and showers were clean. We loved how close to the water we could be at short notice. Love the radio free area so not to have to deal with partiers. Will definitely be back.

name: Darlington Provincial Park
text: First time visiting park. Spent 2 hours walking various trails and roads admiring birds and squirrels, plus taking in beautiful views of Lake Ontario. Picture shown is from shores of Lake Ontario overlooking McLaughlin Bay at sunset. Definitely worth a visit!

name: Darlington Provincial Park
text:
Not a bad park. Staff are friendly and helpful. Washrooms are well maintained and store has great ice cream. Sites are a good size too. Improvements that could be made;
Some sites are not private at all. Our site had a water tap in the corner so people were constantly walking past to a point we ended up moving sites. Next site had hydro post right in the middle so neighborhoods had to walk in to plug in. Again not very private.

Washrooms are good but they could use more to service such a large park. Even just some portables would be fine even if just on long weekends.

Park store ran out of a lot of supplies during labour day weekend. Understandably it's the last long weekend of summer but people still pay full price to camp and should be offered full service.

Trains are LOUD and blow horns in the middle of the night, not sure if anything can be done about that.

I would propably return since it is a close distance to Toronto.

name: Darlington Provincial Park
text: Darlington was a great experience but for a campground, I can't say it was as enjoyable as a place like Presquile or Algonquin. The main issue is how close it is to the train tracks. I live nearby a train line, so I was used to it but late night train honks were annoying. It wasn't as.. camping as some other camp grounds. It's much different from other campgrounds, sadly it's more artificial then Algonquin and such but it's still pretty nice. The beach was freezing during the summer. The staff were nice and calm and we never had any trouble with them. It wasn't far from home and it was rather nice being able to go home once because of reasons. It's not the best campground but for a last minute choice, it was really good. If you can, go somewhere else. Either way, it's not bad.

name: Darlington Provincial Park
text: Camping was fun! Great first time experience for me. Campsite was clean. Huge too. Public washrooms were decent at the beginning, but as time went by, you'd expect them to be maintained - but nope! Overall the beach there is good. Clean. Huge problem is that there are stones and rocks instead of sand. :D you've to swim away from the shore for about 25m to 35m to get proper sand at the base. Radio free and electric zones were good! Quiet. Overall, nice experience!

name: Driftwood Provincial Park
text: Beautiful park with many sites right on the water. Great for families or groups of friends. You can watch your kids play in the water from the comfort of your own site. Go for walks in the gorgeous woods, but do keep in mind that they no longer groom it, to keep it more "natural", or whatever hipsters are calling it these days. They offer kayak/canoe rentals at fair prices. Ice has gone up in price over the years to $4.25 a bag! Campground can be somewhat noisy, depending on who's camping, but it's still a very peaceful place. Book your site well in advance!

name: Driftwood Provincial Park
text: First time at Driftwood and it was beautiful. Very nice grounds. You have vault toilets which are glorified outhouses but with flushing toilets and a sink with foaming soap to wash up. They were clean. Then you have the main washrooms with private showers on the side and a laundry room next to it. Showers are free. Awesome. Firewood was surprisingly only $8 a bag. You get alot. Canoe rental is $35 for 4 hours or $55 for 8 hours or $195 for 5 days. Had an amazing time.

name: Driftwood Provincial Park
text:
This is a tough one.  Many of the sites are gorgeous, but the park itself isn't (or wasn't, for us) particularly peaceful.  Seems to be a magnet for people who want to bring all of their dogs and party.

I'd give it a 5 if it wasn't for the noise.  Perhaps splitting one side into a quiet side and another into an anything goes side would work.  In the meantime,  be aware.  Also, the Giant Tiger in Deep River sells cheap earplugs

name: Driftwood Provincial Park
text: I grew up nearby. I love to spend time in the area. So many memories. Just like any place you might visit there are so many things to see and do. But since I grew up there I know where to go and what I want to do. Like swimming in the Ottawa River is nice. Also check out Swisha in Quebec. There's a waterfall close by where you could swim. Quite nice!! If you stay at driftwood park you will see some beautiful sunsets by the river.

name: Driftwood Provincial Park
text: Very clean facilities (bathrooms/convenience stations are well maintained), easy access to the water from most sites (Ottawa East site). Fire pits are all very new and have a removable cooking grill. Our site had good privacy, but some are not very private (do your research on the ON Parks site - there are pics of each site with descriptions). Great beach area and Driftwood Bay/Ottawa River is awesome for canoeing/kayaking. Fishing was good too.

name: Earl Rowe Provincial Park
text: It's a beautiful getaway for summer. The park it's clean and well maintained and the access fee is reasonable. The staff is very helpful and friendly. There is a pool which is gorgeous, with lifeguards and some shade. There is a lake with sand beech, but I do not advice anyone to swim there as the water was manure smelling from far away. This is the reason I didn't rate it 5 stars. There are a lot of parking lots, able to accommodate plenty of cars, even during the long weekends when it's highly busy.

name: Earl Rowe Provincial Park
text: I ran a half marathon through the park and had a grand time. The park looks like it would be a fun place to come and stay!

name: Earl Rowe Provincial Park
text: Our own little secret in Alliston!  If you have been here before, you'll come again.  Great place just located minutes away of great amenities if you need last minute things.  Fun trails, picnic spots, water fun and well kept.  See you there!👍

name: Earl Rowe Provincial Park
text: Absolutely beautiful. I would definitely recommend Earl Rowe. Throughout my week long trip, there was only one downside, the unsafe beach. The pool is lovely, the campsites are wonderful, the staff are very helpful. There are some very lovely trails that were so neat. This is one of my favourite campgrounds.

name: Earl Rowe Provincial Park
text: Arrived at check in and set up. Decided to swim afterward... Beach was closed due to bacteria levels. Totally fine, can't be helped or predicted and besides there's a pool... IF YOU PAY EXTRA. Seriously. Makes sense for day trippers, but PAID campers should not have to pay to use something at the park that they are already paying for?? ... ESPECIALLY when the beach is closed and pool is only option. As well, it should be noted that the pool (though incredibly beautiful and large) needs more frequent cleaning in high traffic times. Swimming with hairballs was a tad daunting. Definitely a nice spot, but I believe this is a legitimate complaint. Beach is closed, this is an unpredictable occurrence, but in cases like these, allow paid campers to use the pool at no charge. A little customer service goes a long way.

name: Emily Provincial Park
text: Excellent park. Came here as a kid and brought my family here in June of 2018. Pigeon river is very weedy for fishing but if you find a spot you can get some nice fish bass/musky. Facilities were clean and the beach was consistently ranked in the mornings. Awesome dock for your boat/fishing as well.

name: Emily Provincial Park
text: Nice park to visit during summer months. Charcoal Barbecue is allowed. Children’s play area is nearby the water.

name: Emily Provincial Park
text: I had a fantastic time at Emily park. Was there for 6 nights with 3 kids ages 8 to 10. They enjoyed their time at the south beach, swimming, fishing and walking the short trails. Truly speaking, the park and what it has to offer is good. Especially the early morning nature noise that came from the birds, chipmunks and owl. Sweet wake up calls. The beach is cleaned every morning so it is clean and the added bonus is the free fishing lesson and free fishing material rental for. The only reason why I am not giving it a 5 rating is due the noise that comes from the main road across the river. I was hoping for minimal traffic noise.  I kept hearing cars and what sounded like trucks pass through out the night. A little bothersome when the main reason I left the city and drove for 2 hours to get there is to escape traffic noise.

name: Emily Provincial Park
text: Have been going here since my childhood and it's a fantastic park for camping. The trails are great, they've done lots of work on them.  Every campsite has decent privacy on at least 2 sides from my experience. Washrooms are always in good shape. Sure, the beach is really seaweedy, but it's still a great beach to enjoy a day on. Nice parks for the kids, a lot of interconnected campsites for families and friends to camp together but separately. Always a good experience here. Camp your heart out!

name: Emily Provincial Park
text: We had a great experience at Emily park. I think it definitely depends on what type of camping you're looking for. We could hear a lot of other people but the wardens must have done a good job as they mostly quieted down shortly after 11. The beach was well kept and raked each morning. It is a very weedy beach but that didn't bother us. The bathrooms could have been cleaner. Garbage was often overflowing and the toilet paper was gone a couple times during our stay. Our site however was lovely and well treed. There was wooded sections for the kids to explore which they really enjoyed. Overall it was a great park with friendly staff.

name: Esker Lakes Provincial Park
text: Quiet, relaxing, family friendly beaches & walking trails with great campsites close to washrooms & showers. Excellent fishing & boating lake right from the campsites.

name: Esker Lakes Provincial Park
text: Amazing place to camp. Worth the drive

name: Esker Lakes Provincial Park
text: Nice family camping. There was a blueberry festival were we picked up some in a trail but there were also plenty on the roadsides of the campsite. Also nice beach.

name: Esker Lakes Provincial Park
text: Beautiful park with very private sites

name: Esker Lakes Provincial Park
text: Lovely campground. Nice private sites. Playground, canoes and paddle boarding. Very scenic. Prepare for mosquitoes though.

name: Fairbank Provincial Park
text: Wanted to share our experience at Fairbank Provincial Campground. We had a great time even though there was a fire ban on, and it rained off and on. Our experience was great because of one of the Park Attendants' - Julie!! She has a wealth of knowledge about everything going on in the park!! We cannot thank you enough, Julie! Thanks for ensuring we got all the details for our stay! It was our pleasure talking with you.

name: Fairbank Provincial Park
text: Great campground. Lots of seasonal RVs so most campgrounds are reserved with no occupants actually being there, so it's fairly empty and private. Showers, toilets, and laundry equipment are fairly dated and not super clean. The lake and beach are freaking amazing, clear water with a rocky ground. Great for boating and canoeing. Nice small boat launch but needs cleats. Not appropriate for fishing. Pets must be on leash but people are obnoxious and tend to set their pets free to harrass others, park staff don't seem to care. There's a beautiful trail with a great panoramic view of the lake, short hike (45 minutes) but challenging. There was a fire ban so having no campfire was a bit disappointing, but justified of course. Very good experience overall.

name: Fairbank Provincial Park
text: The lake is pretty and the water is clear. There is one comfort station for the whole park, and it could use a face lift. There was a one minute boil water advisory in place while we stayed here, from their state of the art water treatment facility. There is one small short challenging walking trail that leads up to a beautiful overview of most of the lake here. The road into the park is a mix of gravel, pavement segments, and stretches of multiple pothole repairs, and as just about everyone who comes here brings a trailer, the drive in can be a long slow painful one. A lot of people stay here for one night as a pass thru off the Trans-Canada highway. There are some very nice serviced sites right on the lake edge, if I was coming back I would definitely book one of these.

name: Fairbank Provincial Park
text: Amazing lake, spring fed making it very clear. The lake allows boats which is cool and the park is super awesome as it's very sleepy and laid back.

name: Fairbank Provincial Park
text: Always a great time, three separate beaches, lots of sites, bathrooms, and potable water. Our family loves this campground.

name: Ferris Provincial Park
text:
Beautiful, beautiful park.

I enjoyed going here even as a young kid, riding her bike through it. I spent many hours working out here and saw varying forms of wildlife such as foxes, raccoons, bear, and deer.

It's the kind of quiet place you seek when your mind and body needs a break from everyday life.

The facilities are always clean and properly maintained, and the staff (when you see them in the park itself) are always friendly and willing to help a lost soul find the right path home!

name: Ferris Provincial Park
text: Nice camping sites. Few trails to go on. Enjoyed the Ranney Falls trail, the falls, the suspension bridge  and the turtles. On the downside there is no lake within campground. Only swimming is in an indoor pool. Being a very warm weekend we had find natural water to dip in which was a half hours drive.

name: Ferris Provincial Park
text: This was our very first trip to the park. Parker was incredibly helpful at the main kiosk, great addition to the team! Beautiful views and trails to walk around different areas of the park. Of course the views from the Trellis bridge are the main draw, and they are worth the walk. I would recommend this spot to anyone!

name: Ferris Provincial Park
text: Simply beautiful.  Summer or winter. A fantastic place to visit.

name: Ferris Provincial Park
text: It’s a park! Got in late when it got dark. So it was a bit of an effort to find my place (bicycling in). Sucks that it’s 40 bucks just to shower/sleep and leave the moment it’s light again. But hey. I like to support Park system.

name: Finlayson Point Provincial Park
text: Very clean park with well maintained grounds, friendly staff and great fishing!! The docks could use a bit of work but other than that this place is excellent. I come here every year and am never disappointed.

name: Finlayson Point Provincial Park
text: This park has character.  The sites can very significantly but I liked most I saw.  Ours was small but unique. The beaches are very small and in many parts of the park you can either hear the highway, float plain or train.  The boat ramp and docks were solid.  It is a great option for a night or two but not an extended stay unless you are looking for boating access.

name: Finlayson Point Provincial Park
text: Love this park!! The staff is amazing and friendly and so very helpful. This was our first non electric site with our 21ft trailer! Great spot right by the lake. Lots of private sites to choose from.  Highly recommended and Will definitely be rebooking❤❤❤🎣🛩

name: Finlayson Point Provincial Park
text: Nice surprise. Park has many dimensions from shoreline sites to rugged natural Canadian Shield sites. Staff have been very helpful and friendly. Haven't checked out any trails yet but that's next.

name: Finlayson Point Provincial Park
text: Great park, A little small but friendly staff. Nice and close to the town for supplies

name: Fitzroy Provincial Park
text: Nice park close to town.  Both the large public Beach and the small campers beach are nice.  We prefer the Two Rivers campground with sites along the Carp River.  You can walk past the main beach right into town.

name: Fitzroy Provincial Park
text:
Only families with young kids who are in bed by 9pm should go to this place!!
Don’t go there with a bunch of friends though. You talk too loud and “security” will barge on your site like a heard of elephants. 
The lot beside us who were just sitting around camp fire at night playing cards and listening to music. Security snuck up like they were part of a swat team and were very rude saying if they didn’t keep it down they would be thrown out. I was beside their site, just my son and I and I didn’t think they were loud at all! 
6am the following morning the site across from me had young children yelling back and forth to each other and parents yelling way down the road to their children who were unsupervised “be nice to your sister, don’t poke your brother with sticks, come get a snack, breakfast is almost ready, stop fighting!” They were never addressed for their loud behaviour! 

They pick and choose who they want to deal with! 

I guess it makes security feel like the police officers they always wanted to be but never made it! 🙄

name: Fitzroy Provincial Park
text: I wanted to take a vacation from my job one year and decided to go camping. I saw that Fitzroy park had camping and canoeing and thought it would be fun. However, when I was sitting at my campfire at night when I was making some smores I was slowly attacked by countless raccoons. I couldn't count them all they just seemed everywhere and I only had one bag with all my food in it right beside me. Luckily I had a stick and was able to knock the ground and branches to scare them off. Completely horrified I put everything in my car and slept in there. The next day when I was leaving I thought I would bring up the incident to the camp ground staff. So on my way out I stopped into the office cabin. After describing what had happened they told me that I was lying and had made up the story. They said raccoons never do that here. He then called the police on me because he thought I was smoking weed. And when the police arrived they followed me all the way to my house. He said my site was a mess but there was already bits and pieces of trash all over the campsite that I even cleaned up for them. I don't go out anymore. I don't go on vacations. I don't enjoy camping anymore, I don't like camping anymore because when I went they tried to put me in jail I don't like people when I camp I don't  want

name: Fitzroy Provincial Park
text:
Great place for a picnic or for a weekend camping.

Prices are reasonable for either option, with a reserved campground for people with disability.

Campgrounds and beach areas have nice BBQ areas to make your food.

A store on site has most of the treats and snacks you might want.

Where can you find a beach that charge you just $10 per car, not per person, per day?

Showers and toilets are available and campgrounds are optional with electricity.

Great place , reservation is recommended way ahead on long weekends.

name: Fitzroy Provincial Park
text: I haven't gone camping in many years. I came here with my family for a week, and it was beautiful. It was peaceful and nice. I enjoyed my stay very much, the place had a great trail that I was able to run everyday, and it was quiet and well kept. After coming here for the week, I can't wait to go camping here again. I had a very positive experience!

name: Forks of the Credit Provincial Park
text: Great park that has a lot of different areas to explore and take great photos. The waterfall area at the end was a little hard to get any photos of but still a great little hike. A deer actually jumped right in front of us while we we're walking which really added to the experience. Fall time is definitely a great time as there is so much color with all the trees and foilage changing.

name: Forks of the Credit Provincial Park
text:
A great place to ride. Never I did missed going here during the riding season. Refreshing atmosphere after a long ride.

It's either grab an ice cream, a cup of coffee/beverages or just a quick stop and again hit on the road.

name: Forks of the Credit Provincial Park
text: An amazing park. We went on a 3 hour hike up to the waterfall with my 7 month old in a sling and 2 year old walking/ riding on daddy's back. It was quite the hike, but we got some amazing family pictures. Do not take a stroller or bike if you plan to go up to the falls!

name: Forks of the Credit Provincial Park
text: It's so beautiful here! I definitely recommend hiking all the way down to the waterfalls.

name: Forks of the Credit Provincial Park
text: Great little park. Easy walking and very scenic. There were toilets at the carpark as well as further into the park. Easily conquerable in half a day. Probably about 10km worth of trails all up. Beautiful fall colors and the cataract falls were very pretty.

name: French River Provincial Park
text: Nice waterways. Campsites overused. Some nice backwater home to some rare turtles

name: French River Provincial Park
text: This is the greatest place on planet Earth. I have traveled near and far searching for a true paradise and this is where I found it. At French River Provincial Park. You want wildlife? You got it here. Leagues of flora and fauna surround you at all times as the river rich in history glides past you. There truly is no place like it. 10/10

name: French River Provincial Park
text: Beautiful and tote which is it's good and bad. Would be great if there was more public access points

name: French River Provincial Park
text: Fantastic time, as always! Love staying at the family cabin on the French River, every year.

name: French River Provincial Park
text: Beautiful area wonderful place to visit if you love nature

name: Frontenac Provincial Park
text: This is a really nice park with some very scenic hiking and paddling opportunities. I'd recommend this place to all back country enthusiasts.

name: Frontenac Provincial Park
text: Supremely well maintained! Signs are all excellent, there was zero trash anywhere. Everything was perfect. Even the lakes are nice clean lakes that taste excellent once filtered. Staff was ultra friendly and knowledgeable. Fantastic place to spend a couple of nights.

name: Frontenac Provincial Park
text:
Went on the May long weekend to Camp 7 site C.

Hiking to the camp site is 5 kms from the office parking lot, however the incline/decline can be +/- 80feet in some locations.

The trail is pretty well maintained however over the course of the winter some larger trees have fallen over selections of the trail that require minimal deviations.

The mosquitoes are the worst of the trip, however with a good current of wind from the river and/or fire smoke they can be tamed. After 8pm they all but disappeared every night.

Each site at camp 7 had it's own 'bear box' (pictures), picnic tables and grill fire pit.

These items added more security and reveal knowing bears aren't an issue, there is a place to sit for meals and the food we bring can be luxurious in taste. We had steak the first night, chicken breasts for second and third nights. 

There is plenty of fire wood and material on the ground to use to start a fire, but having fire starters (lint from dryer and fire starters from dollar store) worked wonders for Day 2 when it heavily rained all day/night.

If you plan a long stay make sure to have a day pack with your expedition pack to insure you can travel to other parts of the Park and it is a must to purchase a detailed park map which can aid in your exploration.

Frontenac park has more to offer so do your research and call the office to be informed.

October 14, 2018

Camp at site 11a

Amaxing view of the lake and stars. Perfect spot for privacy and close enough to kingsford dam parking area to go back to get resupply or beer.

name: Frontenac Provincial Park
text: Just about my favourite place to hike, ever! And it's rarely busy, you won't bump into a lot of people on most of the trails (well, the ones that aren't right near the main office). The scenery is ever-changing and you won't get bored. Remember to get a parking pass and display it!

name: Frontenac Provincial Park
text: Expansive trail network on classic rocky frontenac terrain. Interesting info center and well-maintained campsites for canoeing or hiking.

name: Fushimi Lake Provincial Park
text: We probably were there at the wrong time the mosquitoes were ferocious and there was no assistance to help find a camp site at 5 pm. It also seemed much further away than the signs indicated. Please try to get the mosquito numbers down it would be nice then.

name: Fushimi Lake Provincial Park
text: My new favorite campground. Beautiful sites right on the water.  Nice lake for paddling. Lots of pike in the lake. Walking trails could be better maintained.

name: Fushimi Lake Provincial Park
text: Started out as a nice park but the site we were given was unsuitable and we wanted to pick another site but there was no one at the gate at 5 pm on a Sunday and a sign stated that the office was closed on Monday and there was no phone number to contact anyone. We picked another site but were worried that someone was going to show up in the middle of the night looking for their site. How can a provincial park be unmanned , especially on a weekend? Tap water was green and I don't think boiling it would have done any good. Shoddy operation and our night at a Walmart was better than this place.

name: Fushimi Lake Provincial Park
text: Great fishing, great staff. Boat rentals are a smooth and fast process too (book online). If you plan on camping here. Make sure to book 6 months in advance as most campsites fill up quickly.

name: Fushimi Lake Provincial Park
text:
One of the nicer provincial parks.  Loved it here. 

Super quiet

name: Grundy Lake Provincial Park
text:
One of my favourite places!
You won’t regret your stay and the views of the lake are amazing!
Pictures of the lots when booking online can be deceiving but they had no issue changing it up for us.

name: Grundy Lake Provincial Park
text: Great camping. The park has tons of things to do. My 5 year old daughter loved the art/nature activities they had. I enjoyed the ease of renting a canoe as it was delivered directly to my site. I would definitely recommend this provincial park to my friends and family.

name: Grundy Lake Provincial Park
text: We had a blast. Kids saw lots of animals, safe for riding bikes and playing with other campers. Gorgeous views and fun cliff jumping!

name: Grundy Lake Provincial Park
text: Great camping experience. One of my favorite campgrounds and parks because it's the cleanest and the environment is the best overall. They have a variety of sites available, including electronic, trailer and group sites. If you want a place to go camping at I highly recommend here.

name: Grundy Lake Provincial Park
text: This park is absolutely beautiful. The sites are large, clean and close to relief stations. There are lots of hiking trails and various lakes to explore via kayak, canoe or paddle board. The staff are friendly and always willing to help! The comfort stations are cleaned regularly and are newly revamped.

name: Halfway Lake Provincial Park
text: The beaches are amazing!! Sand clean and great shallow water depth throughout the swimming area. Park stores are always full of necessities and wonderful trinkets. The park here is old fashioned but entertaining none the less. Parks staff are very welcoming and helpful.

name: Halfway Lake Provincial Park
text: Great park for families. Sites are spaced out enough that you aren't sitting on top of your neighbor. Large and clean public beach.  Dog friendly but remember to bring a long lead since dogs are to remain leashed.

name: Halfway Lake Provincial Park
text: We always like to come back to Halfway Lake Provincial Park. A lot of memories for us. It is away from the city with lots of area and trails to roam. Beautiful setting on the lake and good fishing.

name: Halfway Lake Provincial Park
text: Very peaceful park. Beach is nice enough to hangout on hot sunny day. Staff was kind and helpful. Few site does have waterfront. We had one of these and had lots of fun in our inflatable boat all day long. Site num 93 is highly preferred.

name: Halfway Lake Provincial Park
text: Fishing was great. Staff was friendly. Nice place to clean fish before bringing them home

name: Inverhuron Provincial Park
text: Fantastic campsite. Can't wait to stay longer next time three nights doesn't seem like enough. Lots of paths and trails love the swimming area. Both Rocky and Sandy areas depending on what you want to do. Kids enjoy jumping off the rocks. If you are a camping advocate this place is a must.

name: Inverhuron Provincial Park
text:
Recently updated facilities and sites. Very private large sites. This place needs a huge upgrade of the electrical for the serviced site.
we needed 100 for of electrical cord to reach the plug-in. Luckily the camp store rents out extra cable for free with a deposit. 
The beach wasn't very good. The beach for swimming was very small for the size of the lake front. But this is due to the nature of the area being natural rocky. Great trails for exploring and so many trees. Great staff that was always looking to help with our stay.

name: Inverhuron Provincial Park
text:
We loved camping here!!  You can choose from private, semi private or general camping sites. A beautiful sun set can be seen from the beach at the park.  The men's and women's washrooms were both nice and clean. Park reps were great to interact with and very helpful with locations and directions when we were enquiring.  

They book up well in advance, so be sure to plan ahead.

name: Inverhuron Provincial Park
text:
Stayed in one of the rental cabins (built just last year I believe).  

Cabin was quite nice, very clean, in the shade most of the day so it didn’t get too hot.  Cabin features a microwave, small fridge (with icebox), coffee maker, inside fireplace, electricity, really nice gas barbecue, fire pit, and fresh (drinkable) water spout at edge of lot.  Spacious parking for (at least) 2 vehicles, and double bunk beds which sleeps 4 (bottom bunks are a bit wider, could probably fit 2 kids).  

Cabins are right beside the “rock beach”, and Inverhuron also features a larger “sand beach” which is a short walk or drive to the other side of the park.  

Park and washrooms were very clean (especially for a provincial park) and the staff were very pleasant and energetic.

Plenty of wildlife encounters (which the kids enjoyed), got to see a Hummingbird, Common Loon, Garter Snake, Crayfish, and several Frogs and Turkey Vultures.

name: Inverhuron Provincial Park
text: Beautiful provincial park...great for biking, exploring...even an old settlers cemetery to respectfully visit.  Beach is great.  Sites in Holmes Bay are spacious and private.  Staff is helpful and friendly.  Love it...we have returned again and again!

name: Ivanhoe Lake Provincial Park
text: The good is it is far away from any major towns and has wonderful night skies.  The staff went above and beyond.  The lake is very nice with lots of fishing options.   The park for kids was old but big and fun. The beach at the park was great for little kids and was shallow for several hundred feet.  Restrooms were ok.  The biggest problem I had was that the sites had no privacy and were packed together.

name: Ivanhoe Lake Provincial Park
text: A Little Timmy's trailer park ,not many nice site left over ,all the seasonal folks grab them up. They park all their ATVs on there sites washing them and Dragging there blue honey pots every day to the waste area or hooking up there hoses and hoses to the water spout for miles on end to full there water tanks.The park does not feel like a Ontario provincial park. Besides living in a little Timmons trailer park the beach is beautiful.

name: Ivanhoe Lake Provincial Park
text: After30 yrs. The park is still the same..perfect. Great staff..good fishing..relaxing

name: Ivanhoe Lake Provincial Park
text: Was a great place until it became the Timmins trailer park with generators running all the time and complaints falling upon deaf ears. Wind back the clock 20 years and I'd go back, until then there's better places to go.

name: Ivanhoe Lake Provincial Park
text: Went just for the afternoon from Timmins and wandered around the bog, beautiful park.

name: John E. Pearce Provincial Park
text: It was an adventurous climb down the slippery, muddy cliffs to get to the water. The water was too muddy to swim. So we didn’t. Very rocky shore. I collected some nice pebbles. Extremely solitary. We were there Sunday evening of the August 25, 2018 weekend. So that part is good. Very scenic as I don’t see such muddy cliffs outlining the lake’s shoreline. The scene from above the cliff is nice too. There are hardly any markings and we just crossed a wired fence to climb down to the water. So, do your thing, responsibly. Don’t litter and be safe !

name: John E. Pearce Provincial Park
text: It's ok... you can't actually access the beach anymore, it's all fenced off because of erosion.. it would be good for a picknic or something

name: John E. Pearce Provincial Park
text: Beautiful. Varied habitat, wetlands, coniferous and deciduous forest, grass plains, ravines, hills, lakefront cliffs.

name: John E. Pearce Provincial Park
text: Small, out of the way... but, with a bald eagle in the area and all the history surrounding the park, it makes for an excellent all day venture.

name: John E. Pearce Provincial Park
text: Small park with short road to walk along and a small picnic area.  Water access was fenced off when I was there, so mostly just trees and low lying plants.

name: Kakabeka Falls Provincial Park
text:
One of the most beautiful parks we stayed at lots of walking trails, close to amenities and just a delight. Prices were reasonable. The staff went out of their way to be helpful. They assisted with find a site and bringing firewood. 
An absolute perfect campground and a MUST visit if you are traveling that way!!

name: Kakabeka Falls Provincial Park
text: Campground is very nice, even pull through sites are well treed, back-in sites more private. Only electric hook-ups and they can be quite far away, check site description for distance. Falls are spectacular.

name: Kakabeka Falls Provincial Park
