text: Very nice staff. Waited for our late arrival 10:05 PM. Patient and gave good directions. The trails for your RV are tight and you should bring a long cord for power. Stunning scenery!

name: Kakabeka Falls Provincial Park
text: These falls are deep, resonant cascades that toss up a silver mist so fine and cool, you smile and breathe in deeply to enjoy the whole sensation. Thundering down to the lower portion of the Kaministiqua River, visitors see miriad layers of volcanic rock cut through by the power of rushing water. I have loved this place from the first memories I have of visiting here with my extended family as a child. Then we could get closer, even onto the very rocks the river cut through. The mist shrouds the entire park early mornings. Reminds the traveler of morning walks in the UK & Ireland, enveloped in a shimmering, cool blanket of silver.

name: Kakabeka Falls Provincial Park
text: Great provincial park to camp at, it is a semi private campground with a set of trails of its own and it has a beach.

name: Kap-Kig-Iwan Provincial Park
text: Nice scenery however it is not clear how to get to falls, need some signs , especially if the road is closed for vehicles as it was and therefore people must walk .

name: Kap-Kig-Iwan Provincial Park
text:
I bet this park, in its day, was beautiful. Unfortunately vandals, lack of maintenance and time did a number on this gem. Needs some serious attention. The scenery is breathtaking but is hindered by overgrowth of trees and weeds. The picnic tables are loose and/or broken, the old footbridge is out of service and the campsites are horrible. Not worth what they're charging for admission.  This once was a gorgeous park. 
Also the rates are confusing and overpriced.

name: Kap-Kig-Iwan Provincial Park
text: Really like this park. If you need to get away and enjoy nature. This is a great spot. I proposed to my wife here on a hike. It was beautiful & turned out great!!

name: Kap-Kig-Iwan Provincial Park
text: Beautiful place. Well maintained and awe inspiring.  Perfect day use spots. Nice looking campsites and trailer turn arounds. Reasonable fees.

name: Kap-Kig-Iwan Provincial Park
text: A beautiful peaceful paradise.  Perfect for intimate interludes amongst the flora and fauna.  The romance of the rushing river and tumbling falls all add up to a beautiful experience for couples who appreciate nature. 💖

name: Kawartha Highlands Provincial Park
text:
Great place. Yes you have wildlife that should be left alone.
DON'T CHASE THE LOONS
DON'T CHASE THE TURTLES. If you see a turtle on a road, move it to the side it was going towards.
RUN away from the bears
If you catch fish that can be released, release them. Then someone can catch them later.

name: Kawartha Highlands Provincial Park
text:
After a long and winding drive from the main road Google maps said we had reached - but where?

It was just trees on both sides and a gravel road.It was kind of scary too as it was isolated and very few cars.
I guess we need to make a booking before going to really enjoy it.
I was actually expecting some kind of entrance to the park. I guess we will have to go back one day in the morning and check things out properly.

name: Kawartha Highlands Provincial Park
text: Just wrapped up a trip to site 301 and it was awesome. Shooting stars at night, long swims during the day... you'd almost want the water to be cooler in August. The park staff are amazing. I forgot to display my permit and was ticketed but they voided it. The rangers checked in on us after an adolescent black bear visited our camp to make sure all was copacetic. Boaters are respectful of canoe and kayakers. The site and park at large was immaculate. People clearly take good care of this place. Looking forward to exploring other sections of the park in upcoming trips!

name: Kawartha Highlands Provincial Park
text: Cool trail. Squirrels seem to have a gold tip tail for some reason....

name: Kawartha Highlands Provincial Park
text: Nice trails. And lots of snow at the rite time of year.

name: Kettle Lakes Provincial Park
text: Good sites for small trailers. Tent sites are a little sloppy and quite far from the laundry and shower facilities. The facilities were all clean and well maintained. The water was good tasting - a refreshing change from some other campsites we've had in our travels.  The staff were extremely helpful.

name: Kettle Lakes Provincial Park
text: Very nice and organized camping ground, great beach area. Polite and helpful rangers (staff). Organized events for kids in weekends. Beautiful area, I'd recommend it for anyone looking to camp in the Timmins area.

name: Kettle Lakes Provincial Park
text: There was nobody at the park. Had it pretty much to ourselves. Great site, facilities and landscape. Would go back in a heartbeat!

name: Kettle Lakes Provincial Park
text: I enjoy winter walks and summer swims in this Provincial Park.

name: Kettle Lakes Provincial Park
text: Love the park. Nice place to spend time outdoors. Beautiful trails. Odd campers whom don't control their dogs. Ignorance but not the parks fault.

name: Killarney Provincial Park
text: Awesome and amazing nature, hope to see this preserved for many years to come. The La Cloche trail is great and people on it are nice. Way nicer than people at The Crack. Going through the Crack ruins the experience due to litter, impoliteness, and well it's nearing the end of you're going clockwise.

name: Killarney Provincial Park
text: wonderful, and beautiful. Went four years In a row, and it just as good every time. Pack up, and go for hike with you're friends for a few nights it's great.

name: Killarney Provincial Park
text:
We just went to hike along a trail.  We didn't camp. Parking for the day was 15$.  We took the shortest hike, 
Granite Ridge, posted as mild - moderate, with some steep parts.  It was posted at 1 and a half to 2 hours.  It was beautiful. 

The trails take a lot longer than the posted time, so add at least a quarter of the time unless you want to just hoof it and not stop to enjoy the beauty.  If you take a trail book and stop to read about each spot along the trail, then double the posted trail time.  Hugh variety of nature along the paths.

The steep part of the trail was basically rock climbing. It was a bit difficult in some spots and this was the shortest and easiest of the trails.

So worth it though. The Canadian North is gorgeous.

The hwy to get there off hwy 69 was VERY long. At least an hour of tree lined hwy.

name: Killarney Provincial Park
text: Go ALL THE WAY to the end of the road! GAS is available.  Worth the drive. Fish n chip place is good, shops are cool, Prov park awesome. Went sailing right off the dock, took the tourboat anther time. Very enjoyable!

name: Killarney Provincial Park
text: A beautiful getaway just a few hours north of Toronto. I enjoyed summer hiking and camping in the AB campsites. We even saw a baby black bear run across our site in the morning. This park is what more of Ontario should look like.

name: Killbear Provincial Park
text: Killbear is an amazing place to go camping. There are tons of bike and hiking trails. The lakes and many beaches are beautiful and clean. They have unsupervised cliff jumping for the brave ones in your group. Those who love riding trials bikes, the rocks offer so many cool lines that I will be going back just for that. I also scouted a number of nice rock faces for those wanting to to some top roping.

name: Killbear Provincial Park
text: Can't wait to go here again. Magnificent views from many points. Huge trails did spot few black bears, there is lots to see and explore. The nights are incredible large view of the beautiful night sky its a must see park. Great for couples.

name: Killbear Provincial Park
text:
It’s worth the drive.
We saw some deer.
The air is fresh.
Beautiful and quiet.
A good break from the world.
Meditation is key.

name: Killbear Provincial Park
text: Beautiful park, well maintained, lots to explore for all ages. Areas for swimming, kayaking, hiking, motor boating and of course relaxing. I recommend you bring bicycles as the park is very big. Park staff are well informed at the visitor's centre.  Groceries and amenities are only 35 min away in Parry Sound. Highly recommend!!

name: Killbear Provincial Park
text: Best park to comfortably go car camping in. Lots to see, lots of trails and beautiful beaches. Very clean facilities too. Wide range of campsites, some more private than others. My family enjoys camping at Harold Point best. We will return for years to come.

name: Komoka Provincial Park
text:
As someone from northern Ontario this trail isn’t amazing, although a great place for a leisurely walk there is no challenge here. The park is very well maintained, unfortunately people still leave garbage about. The trail head does have public washrooms with running water so that’s a plus. 

Keep in mind an entrance fee (taken as a parking ticket) is charged.

name: Komoka Provincial Park
text: Great place to take a hike and clear your head.  The trails are will maintained and clean.  The variety of terrain as well as the different trail skill levels make it so you want to hike more and more!

name: Komoka Provincial Park
text: We love hiking here. Parking is now paid, which is $5.25 for 2 hours, as a minimum, however, the trails are great, and scenic. Great place for a family walk or a date, and just minutes from the city

name: Komoka Provincial Park
text:
Great place for a hike. I like the different terrain the trails take. Flat and open, up hill, down hill, rocky , roots sticking out, canopy, big trees, river.
Quite and pristine. This is definitely worth a visit, if you like hiking and the outdoors.
Only negative thing as many people have mentioned. The STUPIDITY of putting the parking lot at the middle of the trail. Having the parking lot at the head or tail of the trail makes more sense to me. The parking fee of $5.25 for 2 hours is just a money grab. I also understand that funding is required to maintain the park. I am not happy about it but willing to pay for the maintenance. 
What I am most upset about is the fact that you have to type in your license plate when you get your parking ticket. WHY ??  If i have paid for 4 hours of parking and only used 2 hours and want to give my ticket to somebody else, then i should be allowed to do that since  have paid for the whole 4 hours. Money grab for sure.

name: Komoka Provincial Park
text:
Even on a cold fall day this provincial park is magical. Set along the Thames River, there are beautiful look outs, wildlife, and a multitude of paths. 

Only downside.. there is a fee for admission.

name: Lady Evelyn-Smoothwater Provincial Park
text: Beautiful area, beautiful view from Maple mountain.  I wish I was here on better sercu stances.  It's so sad to see this massive fire.

name: Lady Evelyn-Smoothwater Provincial Park
text: Definitely world class canoe destination. Less busy than Algonquin. Rugged portages!

name: Lady Evelyn-Smoothwater Provincial Park
text: My fav provincial park yet! Did a back country canoe trip beginning at the Montreal River put in, paddling to Ishpatina Ridge and back. The calmest waters I’ve ever paddled! Avoid Snake Portage unless you are up for a challenge.

name: Lady Evelyn-Smoothwater Provincial Park
text: Wild and quite

name: Lady Evelyn-Smoothwater Provincial Park
text: beautiful area

name: Lake on the Mountain Provincial Park
text: The lake is OK. I mean, it looks like any other of the million lakes we have here in Ontario. Anyways, the view from the parking lot is AMAZING. This is one of the best views of Prince Edward County. Want to impress your Toronto date? Grab something in Picton and bring it here to eat. Way better than sitting in a crowded restaurant where everyone can hear your conversations. Free parking for both lookouts. Washroom facilities in the summer. The ferry is right down the street so it's easy access back to Kingston.

name: Lake on the Mountain Provincial Park
text: Beautiful scenic place. Great for pinics and photos. There isn't a lot of other things to do here. But make sure you get yourself a cheese platter and wine next door before you leave. You won't be sorry.

name: Lake on the Mountain Provincial Park
text: Very beautiful setting ,gorgeous Lake on one side, stunning views on the other. Restaurant is good, plus craft beer.

name: Lake on the Mountain Provincial Park
text: Amazing place. Words cannot describe how beautiful this place is. Plus the way to get there is so pretty.

name: Lake on the Mountain Provincial Park
text: Wonderful place. Lots of great views in the surrounding areas.

name: Lake St. Peter Provincial Park
text:
Great family camping! 
We are at site 45 that has plenty of space and I'd say the best view.  Also close to a smaller beach for easy access for the kids. 

Main beach is great; spacious and clean. There's also beach volleyball as well as yoga in the park on some days. You'd have to check with main office when. 

There are 2 small trails as well. Nothing too crazy, can do them in 30min in running shoes. But gives kids something different to do. 

I'd definitely will come back. Have been here in the past and both times have enjoyed myself.

name: Lake St. Peter Provincial Park
text:
A nice provincial park.
You don't need to book weeks ahead, and it's on a nice lake. However a few of the sites (the lower numbered ones I think) are close to the main road. It also has some campsites with amazing views of the lake. 

The staff are friendly, and there are two nice hiking trails (2.5 and 4km each). The trails are uphill for quite a bit and difficult at times - wear proper footwear. Two of the three marshy areas on the 4km trail had boards to walk on, but the third did not. There are some nice views on the trails, but when I went (mid July) there were a LOT of bugs on them. Make sure to wear and bring bug spray. Overall I was happy with the trail I went on.

The comfort station was clean, however it lacked soap for the first day or so of our stay.

name: Lake St. Peter Provincial Park
text: A little too crowded.  Nice facilities though. If they cut down the campsite density, this place would be a much better frontcountry campground.  Campground beach is small but usable. day use beach is very nice and larger.

name: Lake St. Peter Provincial Park
text: A nice beach & crystal clear lake. Very friendly staff. The sites are quite close & some are not private at all. If you have a large trailer it could be difficult to park. We saw a post get knocked over & trees hit by large trailers bring backed in. A quiet park but no place to properly exercise dogs.

name: Lake St. Peter Provincial Park
text:
The personnel didn't allow the second car being parked at the campsite, even if we paid ! We had to move it outside the campsites, somewhere on the entrance, in  the big parking lot. I understood, for some sites which are small just one car, but if we didn't mind second car being on site and no part of the car was obstructing the road...what's the point? So basically we were paying for a parking, far away same price as in downtown of a big city !
There was also fire-ban, and a lot a lot of mosquitoes, but the park can not do anything about it. The water was also dirty.

name: Lake Superior Provincial Park
text: A great collection of provincial parks arrayed along the North shore of Lake Superior.  We can there at least once each year, and have never been disappointed.  Great place for families or couples

name: Lake Superior Provincial Park
text: Gorgeous views with so much to see. Perfect for people looking to get away. Plenty of activities.

name: Lake Superior Provincial Park
text: Breath taking. Would go back in a heartbeat. The drive is long, but so worth it. If you haven't been to the this part of Ontario, you are missing out. Don't count on the water being warm. We went the second week of August and being the true Canadians that we are, it was quite (shall we say) refreshing.

name: Lake Superior Provincial Park
text: We had a great spot with the lake right in front of us! There was lots to do and see! Showers and bathrooms and laundry facilities. Power hook up was a bit far but we had plenty of cord. The sound of the waves was incredible! A thunder storm rolled through and seemed to hang over the lake for the longest time and the lightening over the lake went on forever! It was incredible.

name: Lake Superior Provincial Park
text: Surprisingly beautiful park just hours north of Sault Ste. Marie. The park has a headquarters with bathroom facilities but is mostly primitive. There is some hiking, canoeing, and several from-the-car strolls. No food except up in Wawa.

name: Long Point Provincial Park
text:
Amazing beach. You would honestly forget that you were in Ontario. White sands and crystal clear, warm and shallow waters. 
I always make the trek from Toronto once if not twice per year (AT LEAST)
Love it.

name: Long Point Provincial Park
text: Beautiful! Sucked that there was no cell service way out there but it was still a lovely beach none the less! And they had a side for the dogs too which was great! My pup absolutely loved his big swim there last summer!

name: Long Point Provincial Park
text: My husband and I love taking our 3 children to Long Point.  It's so beautiful!!!!! They have a dog beach if you love bringing your furry loved one along !! It's so peaceful and clean !

name: Long Point Provincial Park
text: Long point has a nice Long Beach, easy to get your own spot away from other people. Beach water temperature is warm. It’s all sands. No rocks .Perfect for smaller kids and dogs. Campsites are great especially the ones close to the beach. Some has good privacy. The only thing is they don’t really have trails in long point. We went walking by the beach instead which was awesome. Long point is not really ideal for biking because of the sands, it’s everywhere. But I still saw some kids biking by the road. Long Point is perfect ifor families with dogs like we do. We will comeback again for sure!!!

name: Long Point Provincial Park
text: Went to the beach for the day. I couldn't find pricing information ahead of time, but for two adults, it was $14.50 which wasn't too bad. There were people parking outside of the park along the main street and entering the beach via public access points, but where we were in the paid area, it was actually not too crowded for a Saturday and we found a nice secluded spot (for the introvert of the pair...!). No lifeguards, but the beach was clean and well-kept. The water was pretty calm and shallow. Overall a great experience and we'd definitely recommend it, and will hopefully return in the near future!

name: MacGregor Point Provincial Park
text: Great place to camp, especially for those into biking! Been coming here since I was a kid and will continue to come. Private, wooded sites offer excellent privacy. Clean and abundant facilities.  If you’re into fishing you will really have to leave the park and go elsewhere - only a tip , not a critique.  The beach and swimming area are awesome for a good float.

name: MacGregor Point Provincial Park
text: This place is amazing. We went to spend the weekend on a yurt. Perfect for groups up to 6. Very comfortable, with heater, nice beds, table and chairs. Outside an amazing barbecue and a fireplace. Washroom qnd showers 3 minutes away and everything with hot water. This was a perfect weekend.

name: MacGregor Point Provincial Park
text: Great stay in a Yurt on the coldest night of the winter so far.  Cozy and warm by the gas fireplace.  Skating on the oval.  Hike in the woods.  Great day.

name: MacGregor Point Provincial Park
text: Been here quite a few times, it's one of my favourite provincial parks. Numerous walking and biking trails. Sunset point can get busy during sunsets, but there is always a spot for a great view. Big park right next to the beach for the kids. Separate dog beach is very nice. I've met various park hosts and all have been friendly and helpful. In September wild for the arts weekend is a great experience wandering around sites viewing great work by various artists and creative vendors. I have taken my bike on all the trails numerous times and each time is different. Washrooms and showers are kept clean, park staff a friendly and welcoming. This park is highly recommended.

name: MacGregor Point Provincial Park
text:
By far too 5 fav provincial parks. Up there with Shaw’s bay, arrowhead etc. So many amazing trails! Beautiful beach, excellent visitors centre and clean bathrooms!
I even did a free painting class there. I adore this park! Plus, if you go in the off season you can pay by the hour if you wish cheap!!!!

name: MacLeod Provincial Park
text: Really nice area! Staff is good, it's pretty quiet at night for good sleeps and the surrounding area is beautiful! Lake is clean and good for swims

name: MacLeod Provincial Park
text: Little known but great park. Fishings pretty good too

name: MacLeod Provincial Park
text: Wouldn't return. They call themselves a Provincial Park but it doesnt feel like it.

name: MacLeod Provincial Park
text: Not much to do in the area but super park staff and friendly locals. Great place to fish.

name: MacLeod Provincial Park
text: Perfect spot

name: Mara Provincial Park
text: Great park for beginner camping. Have medium size picnic areas. Some spots can be muddy. Good showers and washroom.

name: Mara Provincial Park
text: Found this spot after doing a google search knowing I would be in the Orillia area. It’s a great spot if you are just looking for a nice quiet beach, some hiking trails or a campground.  There is ample parking. The beach itself is large with nicely groomed sand for pleasant walking.  It is not very deep in the roped in area for swimming so it’s great for kids.  I deducted one star because of the washroom. They could do a better job of cleaning it and there were no paper towels and the hand dryer was not working.  Also, Mara does not have a change room near the beach.  Only the above mentioned washroom.  But overall a nice place to visit at a reasonable cost; approximately $14 per vehicle for day use.

name: Mara Provincial Park
text: I stayed at Mara Provincial Park last weekend. We were at a campsite near the end of the park that does a loop. We had 2 secluded campsites for 8 people. Park Wardens were friendly. The beach is huge and busy during the weekends. Would recommend  10/10.

name: Mara Provincial Park
text: Small park with approximately 100 sites. Our site wasn't very private but during the week it wasn't too busy. Beautiful beach within walking distance.

name: Mara Provincial Park
text: Loved it. But I wish they had a sign on how much entrance cost.like q small sign maybe put the cost up front it was 14 dollars and to pay in cash after a certain time for a day pass. But otherwise well worth the price for sure loved it hope they maintain it this way..

name: Mark S. Burnham Provincial Park
text: Went for a fall hike. It was nice but had expected better - perhaps the timing wasn't right. Enough parking spots and short pleasant hike.

name: Mark S. Burnham Provincial Park
text: Beautiful wide trails. Great area!

name: Mark S. Burnham Provincial Park
text: Great little spot to hike. Not the biggest fan of how expensive parking is. Honestly a lot of the time I don't bother paying. $15 for a 30 min walk doesn't make sense when all the other parks and trails are free!

name: Mark S. Burnham Provincial Park
text: Beautiful park for a short walk. I really enjoyed walking through the long trail. I took my time and and struggled to make it last longer than an hour while I waited for my car to be serviced across the street. Close to highway so there a bit of road noise in the picnic area but otherwise a good spot for that.

name: Mark S. Burnham Provincial Park
text: Beautiful place to stop and rest on the drive from Ottawa to Toronto. After a walk or a 15 min snooze ready to hit the road for the rest of the drive. Recently new washrooms but you now have to pay to park. 😞

name: Marten River Provincial Park
text: Prov park closed for the season. Lovely place. Lots of hills to walk sites seem private enough. Beautiful lake. Check the website!

name: Marten River Provincial Park
text: Beautiful vacation spot. Lots of fishing. Well managed.

name: Marten River Provincial Park
text: We love camping here. Large lots and great fishing. Boat rentals right next door if you need. The staff are always helpful and the washrooms and showers are kept impeccably clean.

name: Marten River Provincial Park
text: Nice campground. Water is brackish but fantastic body of water for fishing lots of walleye (pickerel) to be caught. Delicious 😁

name: Marten River Provincial Park
text: We stayed in Chicot A. Very clean showers and washrooms, easy access to the beaches, plenty to do, very cool trails to walk and even with a fire ban in place we had  a great 6 nights. Would definitely go back.

name: McRae Point Provincial Park
text: Well managed Campsite, were in the south side with no electricity yet preffer the North side with electrical outlets. Sand swimming area waist deep. Showers always have hot water. Start your fire early around seven to drive out the mosquitoes. Great nature hikes and nature enhances intimacy.

name: McRae Point Provincial Park
text: I cant say enough great things about this lake and campground. I found this place this past summer and drove 1.5 hours to see it over 10 times during the summer. The lake water is always warm, clear and the little minnows are friendly. Staff keeps these grounds clean and safe

name: McRae Point Provincial Park
text:
Really nice park. They only allow 6 people on a site and they considered my 2 year old niece as a full person so we had to pay for a second site, which felt like a cash grab. Really no reason for the rule to be as such especially with little kids.
We like the lake access here because it's not deep for quite a distance and is a great place for kids to play in the water.

name: McRae Point Provincial Park
text: Great beach and camp sites. Good owners. Shower stalls are clean.

name: McRae Point Provincial Park
text: It was really nice. Lots of areas to see the water and a great picnic beach. It might have been different if it were busier because the sites all seem really close together in the north section but it was good while we were there.

name: Mikisew Provincial Park
text: Enjoyed our stay. We went specifically for our dog because of the secluded dog beach. We found the dog beach very rocky and was hard to navigate into the water with our dog. Other than that a great place to camp

name: Mikisew Provincial Park
text: One of our favorite places to go. Comfort stations are clean, nice sites wooded sites. Hydro and non-hydro sites. Boat launch, probably the nicest beach around.

name: Mikisew Provincial Park
text: This is an excellent park all around!  It may not be a big park like some others but makes up for it in spades with character.  There's something for the whole family here, trails, wetlands, wildlife, beaches, dog areas, canoeing, fishing(licenced only), stargazing, tenting, trailering, you name it.  Put MIKISEW on your list for next year!

name: Mikisew Provincial Park
text: Underrated provincial park. Definitely worth a visit. Super clean facilities all around.

name: Mikisew Provincial Park
text: First time camping here. Stayed at 394. Beautiful tall red pines made the scenery quite spectacular. Despite the lesser foliage, it was still quite private. The beaches were pretty nice and spacious. Clean bathrooms, hot showers. I'd definitely come back.

name: Missinaibi Provincial Park
text: soaking wet

name: Missinaibi Provincial Park
text: wetter than water

name: Missinaibi Provincial Park
text: Very wet.

name: Mississagi Provincial Park
text:
Wish that half stars were an option as I'd like to give this place 3.5 stars! 
I stayed at site #19 for 12 nights. The campsite was okay, not flat at all and the firepit was in an awkward spot, but you basically have your own private beach at the site so it was well worth it! Especially if you have dogs as there are limited spots you can let them go swimming.
Beautiful place! If you are a nature lover looking to get away from it all this is a great place to visit. However, the trails are not that well maintained- so if you are looking for a place with really great trails this is probably not it. 
No showers is definitely a downside, my group also stopped using the vault toilets unless absolutely necessary due to the fact that they are all infested with HUGE wolf spiders. (The handicap bathroom does not have spiders). 
Overall I would definitely come back to this place for a shorter stay, or with an RV or trailer, but probably not for a long trip as I did.

name: Mississagi Provincial Park
text:
This place has become an annual tradition for us.  We have been going up for over a decade and now all my family is involved.

Park staff is friendly, clean lakes, great fishing and a lack of cell service is amazing.  There are few places left that you can truly unplug.

name: Mississagi Provincial Park
text: Paid 12.00 $ day pass to use the provincial park beach. Drove an hour and half to get there. We had our granddaughters for a week and thought it would be a great beach day. Well. The beach is full of leaches. Nobody there not one person. There were dead fish all along the shore. It was disgusting. We asked for our money back with in half an hour and they said NO.  Maybe the camping is good but don’t ever try to swim there!!!

name: Mississagi Provincial Park
text: Worth the drive!  Love this place (other than the deer flies, mosquitoes and black flies).   It’s peaceful and not many motor boats around. They rent out bikes and canoes.  I wish they rent out kayaks or SUP however.   There are a few hiking trails.  Washrooms are primitive.

name: Mississagi Provincial Park
text: Generally a nice and quiet park. We camped here in mid June - two people and a dog. Had a good sleep. Crazy amount of flies and mosquitoes. No cell reception.

name: Mono Cliffs Provincial Park
text: Mono Cliffs is one of my favorite places to spend the day, in any season Plenty of well maintained trails connected to the larger Bruce Trail. The views from the top of the cliffs are awesome. There's always plenty of parking and clean facilities. A small hike away there's also a visitor center and a small lake. I definitely recommend visiting Mono Cliffs.

name: Mono Cliffs Provincial Park
text: Pretty close old place, but I didn’t find this place extremely interesting. We came in the evening and explored just some main trails. It wasn’t bad, but as it was getting dark it became extremely scary. The good thing is that there are picnic tables, so we managed to make a bbq.

name: Mono Cliffs Provincial Park
text: One of my favorite parks close to Toronto. The loop is perfect for a day hike.

name: Mono Cliffs Provincial Park
text:
Ok I've been planning since spring to go here and do the full walk about...the hole trail from start to finish. 
We got there at 8am on a misty day, thinking it wouldn't be busy. Didn't think it was that much to park there, found price bit high for the trails. Would be great if that had flat fees for all the walking trails and parks. I myself found $17.50 for the day and they offered 4 hours $7.50 (we took). With taking the 4 hour parking, we where always watching our time and rushed a bit to see the hole trail. Now I could of spent the hole day there if not for the cost of parking. 
That aside... the beauty on the trails at fall time was without words really. Great place to walk with the kids... that said - parents, kids will get dirty as it's a nature trail (as asked on the way out by a mom) and a misty day. 
Look at some of the photos we got... going to do a girls trip there again! Maybe spring time for new growth.
My walking partner has some pretty nice over the edge photos that are stunning as well.

name: Mono Cliffs Provincial Park
text: Little too icy during the winter. Fell too many times and a ton of bruises. However, the walk is beautiful. Our walk was roughly 3 hours.

name: Murphys Point Provincial Park
text: Excellent campground. Stayed here in a Tent on May long weekend. Good space between sites, good beach and hiking trails. It is also interesting historical area with an old settlement that you can see on a hike. There are also canoe in sites that we will likely try next time. Store was small, but decently stocked

name: Murphys Point Provincial Park
text:
We spent the weekend here and the camping area and beach are wonderful.

Our only issue was the wardens, in 2 night we had 2 complaint about noise. One of the nights was around 10pm, there was 4 of us talking with no music. We were told we were too loud and basically had to whisper. We were not loud at all just normal conversation. the second night the same thing and were then told we would be fined if we continued to " talk" . Through out the night they constantly came by to say we were loud, absolutely ruined the weekend. What a joke! Will not return to this site again. we used to come here with our parent and now we take our kids and wanted to continue the tradition but not anymore!

name: Murphys Point Provincial Park
text: We car camped over the long weekend in Sept here and really enjoyed it although I don't think we fully got to see the whole park. Our site was pretty private but it was a little loud due to a big group staying on the neighbouring sites. The lake was nice and we swam a little ways down from the beach. A little weedy & rocky so I wore my water shoes. Some neat hikes in the area. The silver queen mine sites are well preserved and worth checking out.  Next time we'll try to rent a canoe or kayak as I'd like to get out to the point.

name: Murphys Point Provincial Park
text:
Beach is really nice, canoes are available on site.

My particular camp spot was.. Odd. It was not well distinguished from the one adjacent.

The other one wasn't in use, but if it had been it would have been awkward. Right on top of each other, not so much as a bush for seperate on. They were set up so that each cook location was within 10 ft of the others sleep location. Could have been loud and is probably not "best practice" for keeping critters away from tents.

It did appear that other sites were better, and the hiking nearby was ok.

I will probably go back.

name: Murphys Point Provincial Park
text: Always a blast going here.  Nice clean beach with clear water.  Not a very busy beach every time I’ve visited.  Haven’t camped here but driving through the sites look like a good size.

name: Nagagamisis Provincial Park
text: Most beautiful wilderness park in Northern Ontario....

name: Nagagamisis Provincial Park
text: Nagagamisis Provincial Park offers stunning landscapes and particularly beautiful seas. However, there could be more infrastructures such as walking trails to discover the park even better. You also have to be careful if you plan to swim in one of the lakes because there are some water snakes.

name: Nagagamisis Provincial Park
text: We have been to this park twice now. Both times we were able to reserve waterfront sites which were very good for swimming and boating. Showers at the comfort station were clean and tidy. This is a quiet park with a couple of trails, canoeing adventures and good fishing.

name: Nagagamisis Provincial Park
text: Up tight. No noise after 8 pm. I'd rather camp in the bush where i can make as much noise and get tipsy if i feel like it.

name: Nagagamisis Provincial Park
text: nice place

name: Neys Provincial Park
text: Seriously, this place is heaven. We just finished the Lake Superior Circle Tour and Neys was our favorite place to camp. Peaceful, sandy beach, on the most picturesque bay. Our six year old son couldn’t stop building with the copious amounts of driftwood on the beach. A must-stay if you’re in the area!

name: Neys Provincial Park
text: Beautiful. Majestic Lake Superior.  Good lots. And lots for the family to do. Beautiful park for camping. Highly recommend

name: Neys Provincial Park
text: Very nice campground, well kept.  Privite campsites.  Really nice walking/hiking trails and an off leash dog beach!  Informative visitors centre and has little events/info sessions scheduled.  Would definitely go again.

name: Neys Provincial Park
text: The beach here is like being at the ocean - you just need a little bit of imagination.  Campground areas 1,2, and 3 have sites that have paths directly to the beach.  These areas can be a bit busy.  If you prefer a bit more privacy, area 4 is great for this but it is not next to the lake.

name: Neys Provincial Park
text: Fantastic park. I will return often. Amazing Beach, huge campsites, the stars were incredibly bright, the visitor centre is fantastic for being small, great interpretive programs for the kids and adults alike.

name: North Beach Provincial Park
text:
Clear and shallow waters, perfect for kids and dogs. They have a separate area for pets, it’s not big but doable. 

The shallow water warms up quick in the hot sun. We visited this beach in the middle of September and it was perfect. The dogs enjoyed their time the moment they got back in the car they passed out

name: North Beach Provincial Park
text: I love this beach!! The fact that you have a choice of where to swim.  If you want lake or the bay 😁

name: North Beach Provincial Park
text: With Lake Ontario on one side and North Bay on the other side this park has much to be desired.  The Lake Ontario water has a shallow sandy bottom great for kids.  North Bay on the other side offers warm waters and some nice fishing as well. You can also park very close to the beach which is great for unloading and loading your car. One of my favorite beaches.

name: North Beach Provincial Park
text: If you are looking for a great getaway 1.5 hours east of Toronto. This is where you should go.  At North Beach you get to experience a white sandy beach. Food canteen on site with public outhouse's. Water is very clean and the sand dunes go out at least 750 meters. The beach itself is about 2000 meters long. Great day trip with breathtaking sunset views.

name: North Beach Provincial Park
text:
A great alternative to sandbanks and a great spot for a quick swim.

14.00 vehicle entrance
2.00 walk in from the road, can't be beat.

Obviously smaller than its big brother but the same experience, with both sides of the water accessible. 
Dog friendly, but patrolled much more thoroughly than Sandbanks.

name: Oastler Lake Provincial Park
text:
This place is truly amazing. 
Went camping with friends and we all had a blast. The camp Ground was very nice and very clean. The views are amazing and the beach is awesome. Great for kids for swimming you can walk out and not deep. The cliffs are fun to hand out on and jump off. We are defenetly going back next summer. 
I truly recommend this place for family camping.

name: Oastler Lake Provincial Park
text: Pretty spot but so loud. You can hear the 400 in the distance but the road near the park is closer and louder. But that's nothing compared to the train. Still worth a visit if you want to camp close to Parry Sound. There isn't much to do at the park though unless you brought or rent a boat.

name: Oastler Lake Provincial Park
text: Had a beautiful site on the lake. Lots of people complain about the trains. But honestly didn't bother me all that much. Nice small park with a decent. Beach. Will for sure be going back.

name: Oastler Lake Provincial Park
text: A small but charming park. The gateway to the Massasuaga provincial park. Which is more than charming.

name: Oastler Lake Provincial Park
text: The is a great park. Love the walk in sites for a little more privacy and you get your own shoreline. The only complaint which the park has no control over is the trains nearby at night wake you up at night which was never a problem a long time ago until they rerouted the highway.

name: Obabika River Provincial Park
text: Lady Evelyn Lake is absolutely beautiful!

name: Obabika River Provincial Park
text: Amazing corner of Temagami

name: Obabika River Provincial Park
text: Beautiful clear river with excellent camping some even  have latrines

name: Obabika River Provincial Park
text: Don't go here. It's all mine.

name: Obabika River Provincial Park
text: beautiful

name: Ojibway Provincial Park
text: Drove in from Hamilton, loved everything. Darlene and Ron were more then accommodating, and friendly. We'll be going back.

name: Ojibway Provincial Park
text: Absolutely  beautiful, untouched nature. Great facilities. Nice hiking trails and swimming!

name: Ojibway Provincial Park
text: Relaxing walk through the park.

name: Ojibway Provincial Park
text: It is a wonderful park that has enough wilderness feel that relaxing becomes the normal.

name: Ojibway Provincial Park
text: Great place to camp 😃

name: Ouimet Canyon Provincial Park
text: Wow, a stunning location. The drive off the highway to access the canyon is well worth it. There is a short and easy trail that takes you to two view points over the canyon. There are limited facilities at the park.

name: Ouimet Canyon Provincial Park
text: An easy trail that takes you to two lookouts over the canyon.  Signage at the lookouts explain how the canyon was formed, as well as info about the plant life there. Self serve pay station with a fee of $2 per person . Definitely worth the visit

name: Ouimet Canyon Provincial Park
text: Though it's pretty far off the highway it is definitely worth the trip at least once! Beautiful sights to see! Easy & quick trail.

name: Ouimet Canyon Provincial Park
text:
This place is beautiful and stunning. It was a quick stop and actually smaller than I had expected. I knew the ziplining and what not were way over priced so I decided to fly it instead.
Check out the shots I got. Sorry for the window reflection on some of the shots.

name: Ouimet Canyon Provincial Park
text: Canyon was pretty darn cool! Just wish it was more accessible and there was a way to get to the bottom of the canyon

name: Oxtongue River-Ragged Falls Provincial Park
text: Stopped here for 1 hour and already felt in love with the place. Amazing sound of the waterfalls, the beauty and the strength of the water , and of course the charming and vibrant colors of the falls.... hope I could find better words to describe. The trail was a bit up and down and the rocks on top of the waterfalls would require added care for families with young kids.

name: Oxtongue River-Ragged Falls Provincial Park
text: 🇨🇦👍🏻🥶❄️ Awsome experience ... Short trail from Highway 🛣 60 , 10 minutes walking for a unique experience !!!

name: Oxtongue River-Ragged Falls Provincial Park
text: Nice waterfall to visit. We went during fall too see the foliage. We were late as most of the leaves had already fallen. But the falls was good looking and had a nice time.

name: Oxtongue River-Ragged Falls Provincial Park
text:
This is a hike i recommend you do.  Its only 350 Meters in length but OMG well worth the hike.   Such a Gorgeous view of the water fall.
Go check this out its amazing.   The only flaw is that you have to pay for parking but 5.00 or so is not that expensive at all well worth it.

name: Oxtongue River-Ragged Falls Provincial Park
text:
Beautiful waterfall. Nice trail to get to the lookout - we went on a whim so weren't necessarily dressed for hiking but it wasn't too bad, we just didn't climb down the rocks.

Wardens there at the time putting up a sign were friendly.

If you're going in with a small car beware the huge bump when the drive goes from paved to gravel.

name: Pakwash Provincial Park
text: Nice quiet provincial park. Call if you want a reservation as they are not on the computerized  system

name: Pakwash Provincial Park
text: I have always came here in my childhood and now I bring my child here every weekend to play and explore the beauty of this area.

name: Pancake Bay Provincial Park
text: Good Campsites, although I would avoid the ones that are right next to the highway as there is lots of noise from the passing trucks. Fantastic Beach with great sand and clear water. Water is a little cold, but it is lake Superior. Comfort stations clean and well maintained. Staff at this park were terrific and really went the extra mile to make sure everyone was having a great time. There is a store across the highway about 1 minute away with everything you would need too.

name: Pancake Bay Provincial Park
text: My favourite camping spot!! Clean, sandy, beautiful beaches, great campsite sizes, usually great neighbors & all around wonderful experience. Love it here!

name: Pancake Bay Provincial Park
text: Gorgeous beach! Look forward to returning but they really need to work on the campsite outhouses. We could smell them on the regular from our campsite (not good when you're trying to eat, relax or enjoy campfire!)

name: Pancake Bay Provincial Park
text: Excellent stopover for road trips through sparse Northern Ontario.  Great for camping, and also some of Canada's best wood carvings available nearby.  Nicely located for a stop between Thunder Bay and Sudbury.

name: Pancake Bay Provincial Park
text: Beautiful beach on Lake Superior.  Many nice campsites, but some are way to close to the highway.  I wish they would close the first row and let it fill in with bush as a bit of a buffer.  Suffers the same reservation issues as all Provincial Parks.

name: Petroglyphs Provincial Park
text: Always saw a sign for this place & never stopped to check it until recently. Great learning experience for our little ones but also ourselves. So neat! Perfect educational spot. Long drive in off the main road but we’ll protected. Clean & maintainers nicely!

name: Petroglyphs Provincial Park
text: I'm so impressed with the way that Ontario Provincial Parks has both preserved and continues to protect this sacred site. Staff were very friendly and approachable. Being of First Nation ancestry....I also felt the staff made great accommodations for my family during our visit. The Gathering Centre is full of traditional knowledge. They have some trails to explore. Per car fee is $14.50

name: Petroglyphs Provincial Park
text:
Amazing place. The energy you could feel.  Mike the warden was full of knowledge and a joy to talk with.
I look forward to doing a night visit and hear the water run when the times are correct. 
If you want to see a truly amazing native culture spot come visit. 
Show up with the right frame of mind and truly feel the power in the place.
Enjoy

name: Petroglyphs Provincial Park
text: Great walking tour of ancient human art that has been preserved from the elements for posterity. Truly amazing to behold. An absolute must, at least once. We owe that much to our ancient predecessors who worked so hard to create these.

name: Petroglyphs Provincial Park
text: Nice hiking place to visit for the day from Toronto. The drive was about 3 hours, parking costs 13 CAD and it is advised to bring your own food and water. On a fast walking pace both circuits can be completed in 3 hours. Stopping around the lake to picnic was amazing, and one can bathe too. Spotted some snakes and turtles along the way. The museum and sacred reservoir are also a nice attraction, definitely a nice day getaway for kids and adults. The museum also has beverages and ice cream for purchase and accepts debit and credit cards.

name: Pigeon River Provincial Park
text: Have been to the falls on both the U.S. and Canada sides. The park on the Canadian side is smaller, but there is a lot less foot traffic and the trails are lovely. The trail along the river is rustic, but beautiful.

name: Pigeon River Provincial Park
text: It was a great way to reduce my stress

name: Pigeon River Provincial Park
text: Great park

name: Pinery Provincial Park
text: The Pinery is the best provincial park in South Western Ontario, it has everything you need to enjoy a nature filled get away from the city. You don't have to pack any big sports gear because you  can rent canoes, paddle boats and bicycles at the Pinery store, which is great for loading up on stuff for around the fire. The restaurant has fairly good options and there's ice cream, which is a great way to beat the heat on those long summer days. Or if you're getting tired of the mosquitoes, it's just a short drive from the popular restaurants and shops of Grand Bend

name: Pinery Provincial Park
text: Loved the experience for renting canoe/kayaks, dog beach, biking around the wooded forest and the ice cream is delicious! It’s definitely car camping though and can be a bit crammed for my liking. We are more into backpacking and tried this location as we were with our two dogs under 2 and our toddler son. Surprisingly everyone did well and stayed within our site but I love to be more in the wild and open area!!! We want to come back to the larger campsites near the dog beaches with a group, where we will feel more secluded. Great park overall with a ton of fun activities for young families.

name: Pinery Provincial Park
text: Too many memories too call this an unbiased review, but this place is amazing.  The environment, the trails, the sights, and the sounds of this park are amazing.  I can’t recommend this place any more.  The ultimate escape is just laying in a hammock and listening to those waves of Lake Huron.  Please take some time to make a visit.

name: Pinery Provincial Park
text: Such a beautiful amazing camping park. There aren’t many parks that have so many trees as Pinery! I am happy we got a site right beside the bathroom as some of the sites are really far from bathrooms. The bathrooms were really clean! We are going to go in the summer so we can check out the beach!

name: Pinery Provincial Park
text: Excellent place for camping and activities. Thoroughly enjoyed the stay. It was quite and natural. Biking trail is great. Beaches are serene, could be dangerous due to current. Loved the walk in the dunes.

name: Point Farms Provincial Park
text:
We stayed in Colborne area. Washrooms were kept in very clean condition, sunsets here were breathtaking, trails are well marked and perfect for walking or biking. Beach was great with access ether via the stairs or the road. Park is busy with plenty of campers, but sites are spacious, most are very private even though there so close together. First time camping here and I was impressed with the staff, and the way the park is maintained.

Highly recommended.

name: Point Farms Provincial Park
text: Love this place. Its quiet and clean. Great beach and friendly people. Was our first visit and are making this our yearly camping place. The sound of the waves and the great campsite sold us. Highly recommended.

name: Point Farms Provincial Park
text: Beautiful campground.some great sites with elevated view of lake Huron.easy pull through sites. Park staff friendly and helpful..  awesome dog beach.. excellent sunsets

name: Point Farms Provincial Park
text: Try to go camping here at least once duringbthe year. Our families favorite provincial park. almost had our baby here this year had to leave early to go to hospital. staff were so happy for us that the reimbursed us for our camp site which we only stayed at first 2hours of a five day trip before my son was born.

name: Point Farms Provincial Park
text: This is one of my favourite provincial parks to go camping at, and I've been to quite a few. The group camping spots are very big and there's a lot of privacy between the spots because of the dense trees which I like. The beach is amazing, it's Lake Huron waters and from the group spot you have to walk on a trail then down about 100 steps to get to the water. Is a sandy and rocky beach with benches available

name: Port Bruce Provincial Park
text: Port Bruce is an amazing little port town on lake Erie. The people are nice, beach is amazing. It's one of the last port towns not getting hit with giant homes and beach full of fake tan people. More of a quite let's get drunk and fish kinda town. Plus it has one of my all time favorite restraunts here... the sand castle

name: Port Bruce Provincial Park
text: Most undiscovered Port on Lake Erie. Beautiful, Handicap accessible beach and pier. Great place to live and play and fishw. Three restaurants. Local fish served as well as Shaw's ice cream. Great playground for kids to play on with mini-splash pad. Always something organized for weekend activities during summer. Amazing trailer parks.

name: Port Bruce Provincial Park
text: We had a very peaceful and relaxing time. It wasn't busy and crowded. We had amazing french fries at a little fry truck. We sat on their patio that was like sitting in a tropical setting. We will be going back for sure.

name: Port Bruce Provincial Park
text:
I use to have a trail in the area (cross from beach) and loved my morning walks on the beach. Food stands was something for morning breakfast with far size portion. 
Last visit was not the same place to me, not clean and water was dirty as well. 
We didn't swim there but did try the food and it was ok... again not the same!
Was disappointed to see its gone downhill since I've been last 4yrs ago.

name: Port Bruce Provincial Park
text:
It is a natural beach with little to no maintenance.  It is rocky with driftwood everywhere,. The rocks for the most part range from 6 inches to pea gravel in size. There are large stretches of sand to sit and play in. The beach is clear of litter. There are remnants of illegal campfires. There are few zebra mussel shells around, I believe the rocks and waves grind them up.

It is a great place for a quiet afternoon of reading or relaxing. It is not crowded and there are few children.

There are typical beach restaurants in the area.

name: Port Burwell Provincial Park
text: Absolutely my favorite place to go for either a day trip to the beach, or camping at the park. Beach is all sand, and you can walk out forever with amazing natural sandbanks here and there. There's also a dog beach with tons of space for play time with your pooch either on or off leash. Plenty of space to have lunch and BBQ either with the provided pits or bring your own. Washrooms also available along with taps at a few locations by beach paths so you can wash the sand from your feet. My family and I will always make our way here at least a few times each summer and fall for the migration of the birds. Worth the drive!!!

name: Port Burwell Provincial Park
text:
Love camping here. Lots of activities for the kids and the playground is great too. Clean washrooms/showers.

My only complaint is the beach is a little hike from the parking lot and the boardwalk seems short. But I understand that they don't want to ruin the natural areas.

name: Port Burwell Provincial Park
text:
Great park.
Spacious sites.
Lots of vegetation between sites for excellent privacy.
Large, well groomed beach.
Water is only a few feet deep for about a kilometer out from shore. 
Great for young kids.
Book early in season since sites go quickly.

name: Port Burwell Provincial Park
text:
I love this park! The beach is great. We were there on a long weekend and still had lots of space for beach volleyball and kite flying. The campsites are big and private. The washrooms/showers are new and clean. 
The town is a sleepy relaxed place with some restaurants, marinas, ice cream parlours and shops. It also has a retired military submarine and a real Lake Erie fish market where you can buy fresh Perch. Be sure to rent a kayak at "Otter be here" and paddle down Otter Creek or grab your bike and hit some of the country roads or bring your fishing pole and catch fish off the pier.

name: Port Burwell Provincial Park
text: So beautiful here.  We stayed 1 week on a ravine site. One of the unreservable sites. We were lucky to get it on the last week before school. Truly the nicest sites there. Washrooms facilities were exceptionally clean and lots of showers with HOT water and were free.!!  BONUS.   lots of stuff for kids to do.  Well run park.  Beach is far away but well worth the walk or drive. Stunning beach and great swimming. Loved the area for exploring and shopping.  We found great deals in produce from local Mennonite stalls and farms.

name: Potholes Provincial Park
text:
This place is beautiful!! I go every summer. There are multiple swimming places, many you just have to climb down to. There is a shallow area I always see families near the "entrance". 
If you want to hike, park at the lower parking lots, but if you want to swim, you want to be at the further parking spots. You will still have to walk 10-15 mins to any good spot.

name: Potholes Provincial Park
text: A beautiful place! A hidden gem that isn't usually suggested as a top 10 place to visit in this area. The hike along the trails is a lovely walk.  Beautiful scenery and a fun place to look for bears, but we didn't see any.

name: Potholes Provincial Park
text: Absolutely stunning. Went for a New Years Day hike. Found some fantastic waterfalls - always on the hunt tor falls to shoot. The trail has great little lookouts along the way. Can go as far or short a hike as you want. Different parking lots along the way. Great start to 2019.  Can’t wait to go back

name: Potholes Provincial Park
text: This is one of my favourite place to visit on the island. It very scenic and a great place to take a dip. Water is a little cool so go on a hot summers day.

name: Potholes Provincial Park
text: Beautiful location. In the right weather you can swim, which is a great experience. Cool destination for a half day trip or full day depending on the time you have.

name: Presqu'ile Provincial Park
text:
A treasure located a mere 158KM/ 2hrs drive from downtown Toronto, where so many amazing summer days have been spent. Due to the warm fall in Southern Ontario this year, we even had a beach day in September. The waters here are very shallow and warm up fast and stay warm. Walk out on the soft sandy bottom and gaze at the vast beach far behind you - with water barely up to an adults waist. Go out a little further to find deeper water for swimming. Kids can stay close to the shore and enjoy the shallow warm waters. 

In addition to being a great spot to visit, we love the drive to and from Presqu'ile Park. There really are few places like Prince Edward County. After a few hours on the beach we usually go for a drive and explore the countryside around the park. 

A perfect day-trip for us city-folk looking to forget the rat-race, even for a day.

Note: Bring everything you need - amenities are few and far between at the park. Basic washrooms/ change rooms are located by the beach parking. Stop in Brighton for your supplies on your way there. Also, there is no shelter to speak of, so umbrellas/ tents etc. for shade are recommended, especially if you have little ones.

name: Presqu'ile Provincial Park
text: Beautiful park for a day trip. Not too far from Toronto.  Next to lake Ontario.  Even on the hottest of days you have  a good time as there is a lovely breeze and the water is cool and refreshing.  Lots of nice campsites too.

name: Presqu'ile Provincial Park
text: Beautiful park and always well maintained.  Usually pretty busy during the summer months (as per other Provincial parks).  However, if you go past the busy seasons, and get there early enough, you can catch an epic sunrise and the beautiful colors that come from it.  Also, going early also provides the added benefit of having the park to yourself.

name: Presqu'ile Provincial Park
text: A best relaxing place for a Sunday or any day afternoon. All nature in a good shape. Lots of facilities. You pay for visiting but  it worth it especially in autumn every tree shows a different colour. In addition to forest, beaches and a lagoon and a lighthouse and a natural museum are among the interesting attractive places. You may go inside by a car by a bike or even just walk inside you will love it.

name: Presqu'ile Provincial Park
text:
Their comfort stations were easy to access and open 24hr. However had lots of large spiders. 
Beautiful convenient beach areas with swimming access.

name: Quetico Provincial Park
text: The one and only! Voyageur Wilderness Program is a great place to start and/or finish your trip too! They offer some of the best fully outfitted trips out there!

name: Quetico Provincial Park
text: Really peaceful and super quiet  not many people around. Take the whiskey trail to the pines and enjoy the best beach views.

name: Quetico Provincial Park
text: We canoed from French Lake to The Pines beach. We rented canoes from a Outfitter that keeps the canoes in the park and provide life jackets and paddles. Very reasonable price.  Highly recommended

name: Quetico Provincial Park
text: We stayed at Dawson Trails Campground.  Not a large campground, but great sites, beaches, and trails. Had a couple of times over my 10 day visit where I wish the staff would have tried a bit harder, but overall they were pleasant and helpful.

name: Quetico Provincial Park
text: Peaceful, Beautiful, Quiet... A recommend for sure. They also rent canoes, kayaks and paddleboards. Two gorgeous beaches and even a doggy beach.  Something to do for sure!

name: Rainbow Falls Provincial Park
text: Awesome park, clean and very friendly staff. My wife and I spent 4 days and it was totally worth it. Great kayaking opportunities at the park or nearby on Lake Superior. Highly recommended

name: Rainbow Falls Provincial Park
text: I am bicycle touring around Lake Superior.  Rainbow Falls Provincial Park was a very nice stop for the night along the lake. I had a nice stop to hang a hammock and the attendant let charge my electronics in the shack . Very well taken care of.

name: Rainbow Falls Provincial Park
text: Beautiful falls and a great provincial park. Great camping facilities too

name: Rainbow Falls Provincial Park
text: Great place to hang out and stop moving! Check out the falls and find the Red Chairs!

name: Rainbow Falls Provincial Park
text: The park was breathtaking.  Staff were friendly and helpful.  Fire pit was full of toilet paper and soup cans tinfoil etc. After we cleaned it up we had one of.the best evenings on our holiday.

name: René Brunelle Provincial Park
text: Beautiful Park. Quiet, not too busy. Super clean washrooms and amazing staff especially Park Warden Terry.

name: René Brunelle Provincial Park
text: Nice park. 2 nice trails. Moonbeam trails were nice.

name: René Brunelle Provincial Park
text: Beautiful park and Lake. Very calm and peaceful 👌

name: René Brunelle Provincial Park
text: Populated lake but very private sites. Paddleboards and boats for rent.

name: René Brunelle Provincial Park
text: Good place to stop. Clean facilities

name: Restoule Provincial Park
text: Great park. Stayed here for 8 nights in August of 2018. Plenty of trails and great fishing. Will definitely go back. My favourite park out of the 12 we visited last year.

name: Restoule Provincial Park
text: Overall a nice park... however, we found that the rangers were unreasonable with the rules. For example, we were all speaking very softly and two rangers popped up from the bush and said we were speaking too loudly... this happened twice. Makes me feel very uneasy that these rangers were sitting there in the dark, observing us.

name: Restoule Provincial Park
text:
if u like to eat dust all day from continuing traffic driving on gravel roads between every site then this is the place for you! 
small sites
do not book the sites that have the main gravel roads! !
note photo rendition of our first spot👇
it went downhill from there...

name: Restoule Provincial Park
text: Had the best time ever! Rain never stopped us from having fun. Beautiful beach and dock launch. Big camp sites. Very well kept washrooms and showers. Will be recommending to other and coming back #444

name: Restoule Provincial Park
text: Very nice lake, quite campground. Staff is very friendly and nice. The campsites have 2 picnic tables and are big,  Canoe and bike rentals right there in park, the bikes are really and high quality. nice beach area and hiking trails and a few bike trails. Nice showers and bathrooms at confort stations. Over all great place.

name: Rideau River Provincial Park
text: Place is well kept and maintained. Bathrooms we're dry, clean. The Park persons had bird spotting informative activity for kids. The camp site was good too. It can be great place for a day trip or picnic with family and friends. Parking fee/entry fee is about $15.00.

name: Rideau River Provincial Park
text: was a little hard to find at first, but being our first time out here from alaska what do you expect right? quiet campground and well maintained. we will keep it on our list of nice RV parks to stay at!

name: Rideau River Provincial Park
text:
It's a very good place for a family kids. You can do a lot of activities are there are two beaches for swimming. There's no lifeguard but the water is pretty shallow.
There are campgrounds different campgrounds in this area you can go for camping. You can play beach volleyball there's a net available you have a lot of sitting area barbecue and also a big shed. 
Canoes and kayaks are also available for rent. 
Overall it's a very fun holiday for family with kids with a lots of activities.

name: Rideau River Provincial Park
text: Just on the outskirts of Ottawa, perfect if you just want to get away for a night or the weekend.  One side of the park is close to the highway, so a bit noisy at night.  Wood is kept in a dry place.  Only has one 3km hike.  Large beach.

name: Rideau River Provincial Park
text: Quiet but small park. Wish I could have swam but the bacteria levels were too high. The prices of kayak rentals are honestly way too high so no one was on the water. The facilities are decent. But there isn't much to do without swimming... So I wouldn't recommend more than a night's stay to be honest unless you're just here to sit by the fire quietly

name: Rock Point Provincial Park
text: Awesome campground. It rained almost the whole time we were there, but the kids didn't care. The fossilized rock beds are incredible, and the tiny fossils all along the shoreline kept the kids entertained as mini paleontologists for a whole afternoon. Facilities were clean and the park is well-maintained. Sites in our area were fairly close together, so maybe not the greatest if you're looking for rugged camping, but great for families. No problems bringing the dog.

name: Rock Point Provincial Park
text:
Tons of beach too enjoy. Good size sites.
Clean and relaxing place.

name: Rock Point Provincial Park
text: I was so impressed with this provincial park. Campsites are very nice and clean. Sites are big enough for small group to play games. The Site we had was having good privacy and washrooms were close enough. Beach of this provincial park is very clean and water is good to swim during hot summer time. Beach is very good for morning walk and trails are decent.

name: Rock Point Provincial Park
text: Absolutely beautiful! Fossils and shells are fascinating to explore! Rock platforms and ledges are fun to walk out on or sit/lay in the sun

name: Rock Point Provincial Park
text: Always a fantastic family walk. The views and the nature are abundant.

name: Rondeau Provincial Park
text: Absolutely love this place! It's so beautiful! I went near the end of October and all the fall colours were great. Love the dog beach, it's so big! So many animals around as well, I saw deer more than a handful of times

name: Rondeau Provincial Park
text: Awesome fishing, clean campgrounds, decent beach, do your research on the site you book as there are a lot that are full sun all day with few trees for hanging hammocks or clothes lines. Washroom and shower facilities are clean and mostly bug free.

name: Rondeau Provincial Park
text:
Amazing park. The sites are great, with a mixture of relatively private to spacious and open.  The staff are always friendly and the park store has a pretty good variety of "oops" items that you may have forgotten or run out of... and the food that they make is reasonably priced and delicious.

The beach is also walking distance!!! It's fantastic.

Oh, and the visitor centre? Amazing! The kids absolutely love all the live animals they have -- typically from turtles to reptiles -- but the displays are also fantastic and well done.

The cons:
The beach is a little on the smaller side (depending on the tide) and you're kind of sitting in cottage country, where almost everything you're doing involves going between or around peoples' homes... so there's a disconnect from the camping experience.

name: Rondeau Provincial Park
text: We went in the month of June and had no problem getting a site while other provincial parks were booked up.   The sites aren’t as private as other parks, however we had very few sites booked around us.  Still a great experience.

name: Rondeau Provincial Park
text: Well kept park with beautiful trails. Visitor centre offers guided hikes that my kids love

name: Rushing River Provincial Park
text: Great campground. Lots to do for all ages. I've been coming here for almost 15 years straight, and unfortunately it seems that the park is kind of a forgotten gem... They used to have the museum open more often, as well as have weekend movies at the theater (where they got kids to collect garbage around the area in exchange for popcorn that you could enjoy during the movie), but over the past several years they haven't played anything at the theater and the museum is hardly open, and hasn't been updated since I was a baby... A lot of the roads through the campground are old, have pot holes and need to be filled or redone. Most bathrooms and showers are clean, the outhouses can be quite dirty though. Multiple beaches to choose from which is great, but sadly none are dog-friendly... Overall I love this place, but It hasn't done or changed much over the years and is starting to fall apart it seems. Still very nice, but work and changes are definitely needed.

name: Rushing River Provincial Park
text: I've been coming here every year since I was a baby. Such a wonderful campground with great memories but it is starting to go downhill. The bathrooms are very run down and dirty. The amphitheatre isn't being used anymore which is a real shame. They used to play family movies some nights and have events. Nothing like that happens anymore.

name: Rushing River Provincial Park
text: Went at about 3pm on a Saturday and stayed for 4 hours. Drove in for the day from Winnipeg for the first time to discover. Decent spot bit of a combo of private adult and family spots throughout. Would definitely go back. Had a group of 4 and we were able to BBQ and play music among ourselves without bothering picnic tables within ten feet.

name: Rushing River Provincial Park
text:
Rushing River is an amazing campground. Book like 6 months in advance to secure a prime location on the river/lake. 

The showers are hot and free, and the campground is better kept than most. Good privacy if you pick a treed lot.

name: Rushing River Provincial Park
text: Very good campsite. Waterfall is nice but only thing which was missing is beach so we went to falcon lake for that. Washrooms are clean and tidy. If you want to hike then there are good trails for hiking and cycling.

name: Samuel de Champlain Provincial Park
text: Made the trek from Toronto once for camping and it is definitely has become one of our regular spots for camping for now on. We had a site right by the lake and it was amazing. Rapids were really fun too.

name: Samuel de Champlain Provincial Park
text: This park is incredible! We stayed for the week after Labour Day - and our side of the park emptied out after the long weekend. Staff were friendly and did not bother us. Park bathrooms were clean as were the showers. We can't wait to book our site for next year!

name: Samuel de Champlain Provincial Park
text: An amazing park, with excellent facilities, sites are big with lots of space. Beaches were clean and lots of ample space to wonder and explore. Fishing was good as well. Lots of different water bodies to explorer. Highly recommended for a family adventure. Shower facilities were top notch for a park. Thoroughly enjoyed our stay.

name: Samuel de Champlain Provincial Park
text:
Wonderful woodsy campsites. Quiet and spacious. We had # 174 which has a nice waterview but it was listed at the park store as a "pull-through" ... Which might be true if you were on a motorcycle; otherwise you'd have a tree as a hood ornament!
Really nice flush outhouses but there's a boil water advisory

name: Samuel de Champlain Provincial Park
text:
Amazing park and super friendly park staff..... we had everything as we were told...super clean Comfort Station...with Shower facilities......
Only thing needed more is group possible canoes...like specially for 4 and 8 people.....they had only very limited facilities of those.........We will surely go back in future......

name: Sandbanks Provincial Park
text: My favourite provincial park! Large park with all necessary amenities and a variety of activities. Always fun to hike through the dunes to find yourself a secluded beach spot for the day. Popular place so make sure you book in advance as camping spots are hard to come by!

name: Sandbanks Provincial Park
text: A great vacation spot for a weekend trip. The best fresh water beach that I’ve been to. Make sure to go on a non busy day. During that latter part of the summer, there is a lot of green algae floating around, watch out for that. They have some vineyards around the prince Edward county that are worth a visit as well.

name: Sandbanks Provincial Park
text: Since I'm from Hamilton, I'm used to Lake Ontario being disgusting, green, and toxic. When on my vacation, I came several times to Sandbanks Provincial Park, and it was honestly great! Clean water that you can actually see to the bottom of! It was very busy, but since we were just going to swim, that wasn't a big problem for us. Pretty good destination to go if you're in the area.

name: Sandbanks Provincial Park
text: Sandbanks is generally beautiful, and I remember it fondly from childhood.  sadly, zebra mussels have become a massive problem.  while this isn't the park's fault, it does affect the visitor experience, so I cannot give the park the rating it deserves.

name: Sandbanks Provincial Park
text: Clean, cheap and good for the whole family. It's nice that it hasn't been over run with Americanized stores. There's one store, with minimal selection. the bathrooms are clean. The beach is also clean and garbage free. Sand is usually nice as well. Although would be nice if it were raked once and a while. I think the garbage bins should also be emptied more often, but very minimal issues compared to the whole experience. Definitely recommend!

name: Sandbar Lake Provincial Park
text: Lovely little park!  Beach is perfect for little kids... swimming area is very shallow and sandy.

name: Sandbar Lake Provincial Park
text:
nice on the lake, tons of Mayfly's 
 nice breeze on the lake, you could swim but I would not recommend swimming in early July because there are so many Mayfly carcasses and they wash up on the beach making a dead fish smell.
but I would recommend, the camp site are very private and the ones by the lake have a hiking trail going along the water.  Some parts of the trail lead to rocks that you can sit on and enjoy the coolness.

name: Sandbar Lake Provincial Park
text: I grew up in the town just south of the park. It's a beautiful place to bring the family. The lake is shallow and smooth sandy bottom and the camping sites are clean and well maintained. I have been going there since I was a kid and today my kids enjoy every min wr are there.

name: Sandbar Lake Provincial Park
text: Came in quickly just to look around, the Parks person was friendly and helpful. Beautiful place and the camp sites looked well maintained.

name: Sandbar Lake Provincial Park
text: Lovely small park.  If you arrive after hours (430 pm) they have unreserveable​ sites available and the tent ones are right on the lake!  I had#26 which I could see the red sunset beginning through the trees where my own private path went to the lake.  Large enough rocks to sit on.  I stayed 2 nights last week.  I literally heard no one talking the whole time on my site.  The beach is hardly used.  Nice trail called Rockcliffe. Takes you to top of granite outcropping that gives awesome view of whole lake.  A bald eagle flew over me!  Amazing!  Mosquitos quite bad as there is a lot of standing water but mostly when it's damp out.

name: Sauble Falls Provincial Park
text: Decent campground at Sauble Falls and close to Sauble Beach. Great bathroom, shower facilities. We did see 2 wood roaches during our 4 day stay though.

name: Sauble Falls Provincial Park
text: Excellent customer service and friendly staff. Good site sizes easily accessible. We had parking for 4 cars when friends surprised us with a visit. Short day trip to Sauble Beach was heavenly. Short day trip to Tobermory was breathtaking. Coming home to clean, large, high water pressure showers was terrific. Enjoying the sights of chipmunks everyday, had us buying a bag of peanuts in town, just to watch him dart right up to our hand   and stuff his cheeks, tearing off to who knows where...fun.

name: Sauble Falls Provincial Park
text: These grounds are the least private of all the provincial parks I’ve ever been to. We could see the cars on the highway from our campsite... the highway was on the other side of the fence... not impressed. I would go to a private park next time I’m in Sauble area

name: Sauble Falls Provincial Park
text: Went here to check out the falls and it is very beautiful. It is a tourist attraction so in the warm weather it is packed with people. Parking is expensive but there are a few cheaper lots if you are willing to walk a few minutes. The water was warm and the rocks are slippery so I recommend good water shoes to avoid slipping. Nearby is a place you can rent kayaks and paddle boats which is awesome. This is not a place I'd go swimming but to check out the falls and walk through the water it's a cool place.

name: Sauble Falls Provincial Park
text: Beautiful park worth going .  5 minutes from Sauble beach. Beautiful campsites. Nice clean facilities. Very nice staff. Lots to do in the area.

name: Selkirk Provincial Park
text: August long weekend.... We Went With Family and our 6 friends and their family. This place is not good for camping. Dirty Washroom. No shower in our side of camp ground. Staff are not friendly. We Just ENJOY because of big group. Otherwise this is my worst camp site. Beach is also not good.... Too much..... dirty and stone.  We found plea worm on water which bite our kids too.

name: Selkirk Provincial Park
text: The park has some really private camp sites and it is well maintained. The staff are lovely and our kids enjoyed the art in the park activities. We will absolutely go back!

name: Selkirk Provincial Park
text:
Great camp sites, well maintained common areas/washroom facilities. Beach isn't maintained, very rocky, lots of dead fish/birds. Dog beach is actually nicer than the dog free beach, except for some irresponsible dog owners that don't clean up after their dogs.

There is a good amount of activities to keep kids busy/happy. Decent sized play structure.

Overall it was an good experience.

name: Selkirk Provincial Park
