text: A decent Provincial Park with the usual amenities. The site we booked had good shade and privacy. The beach was okay.

name: Selkirk Provincial Park
text: Nice maintained park, quiet and shadowy. Beach is a bit rocky first 10 feet,  then soft send. Good for swimming and camping. Washrooms are basic, but it's not a Warldorf-Astoria, right?

name: Sharbot Lake Provincial Park
text: It's not the biggest or best equipped of the Ontario Parks, but it's a beautiful little gem and absolutely worth a visit if you're nearby.

name: Sharbot Lake Provincial Park
text:
Clean rest rooms. Must buy their fire wood unfortunately it’s very expensive and super wet! Kayak rentals available. Nice hidden paths where you can dock your kayak and go for a small hike.  Small selection of items to purchase in store but mostly souvenirs. 
PAY ATTENTION TO WHAT LOT YOU PICK!!
Some are right beside the Highway and it’s super loud ALL NIGHT!! Transports going by using their gears to slow down will keep you awake all night!

name: Sharbot Lake Provincial Park
text: One of my favourite parks! Very family friendly. Private sites, large areas for camping equipment. Great swimming and easy Portages. Definitely recommend!

name: Sharbot Lake Provincial Park
text: Nice simple camping. Park is nice, offers some hiking and swimming. I stayed as far from the highway as possible and still could hear trucks, but it's a problem with the location, not the fault of the park or it's staff. Great for a quick camping fix.

name: Sharbot Lake Provincial Park
text: This is well run great little provincial park! We had an amazing site where we could swim right off of it, the weather was sweet, and our neighbours were all quiet & respectful of others! It all added up to an awesome camping trip!

name: Sibbald Point Provincial Park
text: Big provincial park one hour drive from Toronto. Great for any party size of campers great place for fishing boating and swimming. Huge picnic area to spend a day BBQ. Clean facilities. Can get extremely crowded weekends in the summer. Good ice fishing in the winter they have some winter activities you can enjoy.

name: Sibbald Point Provincial Park
text: Its a well maintained Provincial Park, has camping ground. Ample parking$20/vehicle/day (no limit on passengers). Nice picnic areas/shades available if anyone plan & book in advance. Clean beach, more than sufficient playing areas. Bicycle parking & tracks. Propane BBQ is allowed. Has cafeteria with variety of food options, ice cream shop. Boating  and other water sports, fishing and much more, worth visiting!

name: Sibbald Point Provincial Park
text: Nice place for picnic. Water is clean. Shore could have been a bit better. Also a lot of sea weeds in the water.

name: Sibbald Point Provincial Park
text: Went tent camping here for 2 nights. Absolutely loved the facility. Campsites are nicely spaced out between trees and the washroom/bath facility was always clean. Great water sources closeby with clean drinking water. The people who work at the reception area were friendly and accommodating too. Highly recommend a visit here.

name: Sibbald Point Provincial Park
text:
Sibbald Point Provincial Park was a lovely surprise. Our Hardwoods area campsite was easy to access for setup, and provided just the wooded serenity we hoped for.  Public showers/washrooms seemed to be in high demand but both these and the garbage areas were kept reasonably clean. Our camper had  a serious challenge filling with water as the main hose was stripped and could not be properly attached to the rig to fill the tank. Dry camping it was indeed! Such a shame to see so many gallons run off on the gravel road. For a park this busy, the dump/fill area was poor. 

By contrast, the park's day use area was popular and the beach areas -- one for campers/day use and the other where pets were allowed -- were both very crowded with little room for getting into the water to cool down. Beach access is a car/bike ride away from the campsite area, although some did venture the long journey on foot. We would liked to have had the opportunity to visit the park's original homestead/museum. Ran out of time. 

Finally, for those interested in touring local attractions -- Sutton and surrounding area offers a great deal by way of local food, shopping, art, and history, with several park and boating options.

name: Silent Lake Provincial Park
text: Fabulous campground. The electric cabins (200 series) are organized, supplied with necessary resources, and are super comfortable. My friends and I had a really splendid time there on an early December weekend. Also, the park staff are extremely kind and helpful. There are several trails nearby that you can explore, too. As for washrooms, those are located nearby in a public facility.

name: Silent Lake Provincial Park
text: Great little park with excellent hiking trails.  Most sites are spacious, decently private, with park sections for everyone - electrical for trailers, walk-in sites for folks that want a more private experience, well maintained roads and facilities and a couple of nice little beaches.   Winter camping in yurts is a big hit too - all in all, a great park!

name: Silent Lake Provincial Park
text:
This place is beautiful with many beaches and coasts to play on. I definitely recommend you to get a kayak or canoe to explore the shores. We found a nice big rock a little cove and had a blast. 

Went here for the long weekend and I must say that the facilities were amazingly clean. The upkeep of the comfort stations and washroom were incredible. You can constantly see workers come and maintain them throughout the day.

name: Silent Lake Provincial Park
text: My family and I have been camping at silent lake for years and we always have a wonderful time! It’s our go-to location for camping most summers. Good quality camp sites, lots to see and do, helpful staff, and clean environment!

name: Silent Lake Provincial Park
text: Great place to go for a canoe trip and a nice long hike around the lake. Would definitely recommend. Not very busy and super clean and well marked trails

name: Silver Lake Provincial Park
text: This park is good, lots of swamp and wetland to explore, saw lots of wetland wildlife in my 3 day stay.  Excellent sandy beach and lake access with canoe kayak rental available.  It’s a small park so there a little bit of everything and not a lot of sites to spare, so book early.  Although this is a positive review be warned...the park is right on Highway 7 and you can hear the highway 24hrs a day from the park.  For extreme conservationists this park is not for you, it’s completely humanized and recreational. For vacationers and family car campers this is a great park, especially if you have kids.  Keep supporting the Ontario parks, thanks.

name: Silver Lake Provincial Park
text: Nice camping for the whole family. Beaches are kept very clean. We enjoyed fishing/kayaking on the lake. Kids catched half a dozen frogs within our first hour on the ground !

name: Silver Lake Provincial Park
text: Great small provincial park. Campsites on the lake are spacious and have good privacy. Not alot of big size fish. Its great for beginner camping the only down side its near a highway. Washroom and showers are clean. Park has canoing and great views.

name: Silver Lake Provincial Park
text: Good camping experience for the family. Beach and boardwalk trail through the woods. Only downside is sites are close to each other so you may hear your neighbor.

name: Silver Lake Provincial Park
text: Nice provincial park.  Small park with some small sites, however, there are some sites that are fair size for sure.  Beach is clear water and free of seaweed.  Staff are friendly and efficient at keeping the park clean at all times.  Little depends where you are the highway can be noisy from the trucks going by but that quickly gets tuned out and you forget about it. Has some nice sites on the water as well which I’ll need to look into next visit.

name: Sioux Narrows Provincial Park
text: Great experience here! I will definitely be back. Beautiful well kept campground. Clean bathrooms and showers. Super friendly staff who are always driving around making sure you have enough ice and updating you on the weather.

name: Sioux Narrows Provincial Park
text: Favorite beach near Kenora. Crystal clear water (if it's not windy, any North wind). Quite, clean park and a big recreation area with big capacity. Charcoal BBQ available for use. Also drinking water and dressing rooms, washroom available.

name: Sioux Narrows Provincial Park
text: One of the best camping sites I've been to. Nice viarity of sites available, from open sites for campers/rvs to private water front tent sites. Great service, they will deliver ice and wood to your site. They also are very strict about noise, which helps make it a very peaceful campsite.

name: Sioux Narrows Provincial Park
text: Nice staff,  clean bathrooms updated showers. Site was fine (48). Stars were amazing. We needed out Deet as expected.

name: Sioux Narrows Provincial Park
text: Beautiful beach friendly manager that drives around asking if you need anything first time here willbe back

name: Six Mile Lake Provincial Park
text: I find this park is on the muddy sandy side. Great place to camp if your a dog owner. Good place for fishing and boating. Lake views are beautiful.

name: Six Mile Lake Provincial Park
text: This camp site is very clean. Staff roams around a lot. There is 10 hot shower area with washer/dryer however washing machine cost $3 and dryer cost $2. Fire woods $8/bag. Everyone is so friendly. The views are great. Great spot to fish for blue gills for children experience with just a work/hook on the rod. Not much bugs during September in this area. Would come again, very close to Toronto, 2 hour drive at most.

name: Six Mile Lake Provincial Park
text:
Nice clean and QUIET park as far as other campers are concerned. 
It is quite close to the highway, so there is noise from there, but if you bring earplugs it's fine for sleeping.
They're building/renovating a second comfort station, so there's only one that can be accessed for all campers. That comfort station was clean at all times though.
Nice clean beaches, lots of boats to rent and friendly staff. Looking to come again next year.

name: Six Mile Lake Provincial Park
text: Awesome lake full of fishing and clear waters. Caught a few great fish and really enjoyed the scenery of the park. Easy access to boat ramp.

name: Six Mile Lake Provincial Park
text: Beautiful National Park! I’ve done 4 separate long weekends at the park wit some great friends and absolutely loved every minute! The beach is borderline not a beach... but the waters for fishing or boating are perfect. We have also done every hiking trail as well! Great terrain, wonderful views no complaints there. Only thing that could use some proper improvements and the reason this review is a 4 star is the up-keep on the washrooms. They seem to be overflowing every time... Not a pleasant experience.

name: Sleeping Giant Provincial Park
text: I only got to spend little time here as I was traveling through. Though the time spent here was just amazing. The park has much to offer and a lot of wildlife that as a photographer I loved! Not to mention the nature and the trails. There are tons of trails marked out with distances of all kinds. So you can choose how long you want to hike around and explore.

name: Sleeping Giant Provincial Park
text:
A beautiful place to spend a weekend at. That is, of course, if you're into Nature. Well maintained trails, camp grounds and lakes.
Just a beautiful experience overall.

name: Sleeping Giant Provincial Park
text: One of the best hiking spots in Ontario. Lost of trails that vary in lengths and difficulty levels with the more strenuous also being most rewarding. The views from the peaks are world-class and an occasional dip in the frigid waters of Lake Superior will refresh even the most tired hiker.

name: Sleeping Giant Provincial Park
text: I come here twice a year and hike and camp in the interior with my dog. We both love it. Last spring my dog and I hiked all along the Kaybeun Trail from Thunder bay lookout to and around the Giant to south end trailhead. Spent 11 days out there

name: Sleeping Giant Provincial Park
text: Spent a week at sleeping giant and had a fantastic time! We stayed on a water front site 204. It is an electrical site with water just out front and clean vault toilet very close by. A quick walk to the beach and a bike ride to the comfort station and visitors center. The site was quite sloped for our trailer so we had to put leveling blocks under the rear tires and the tongue jack all the way to the bottom to get it level. Gorgeous sunsets and a so many hikes available that we didn't have time to do them all. We did the Sea Lion and Joe Creek Trail. Both short trails Joe Creek had a cool creek you can walk in but not the beautiful view of Lake Superior we were hoping for. We also drove out to the Thunder Bay look out which is a long and rough ride in and a bit steep at times but a very beautiful view if you aren't terrified of heights. We wanted to do the top of the Giant trail (the knees) but it was a long bike then hike in. We were told it would take us about 11 hours return trip. Maybe next time.

name: Springwater Provincial Park
text: A treasure.  Buy a Provincial Park Pass at your favourite park.  That money gives you parking at ALL provincial parks in Ontario. Some money goes towards maintenance of the park you purchased at.

name: Springwater Provincial Park
text:
This place truly is a hidden gem.  Just outside of Barrie, it's a wonderful place to take in the outdoors while walking on several kilometers of trails.  Take the kids, go with a loved one, bring the dogs, bring a picnic lunch ...

There is a small entry fee for vehicles.  Parking is more than adequate, there are washrooms and a modest play area with swings.  Be aware that this area is a lowland. It can be quite wet at times and biting insects can be a great nuisance.

name: Springwater Provincial Park
text: Beautiful park, thank you for having us. We cannot wait to come back and explore more and share it with our children. I used to go to Springwater park with my parents all the time when we were little for cross country skiing, picnics and to enjoy nature. I am glad that it remains open.

name: Springwater Provincial Park
text: Big beautiful park with pavilions. Very clean facility with a lot of parking. Nice location to take kids or have a family picnic/bbq. Lots of trails to walk/bike. I’ve heard it has a nice playground too for children (but I did t look for it).

name: Springwater Provincial Park
text: Gorgeous spot for hiking. You can park at entrance. Trails are well marked.

name: Sturgeon Bay Provincial Park
text: This is a great Provincial Park for camping, but not having actual Comfort stations is a real minus for this park. They charged enough for the sites that they should be able to spend some money and make this even better. This is a very small Park with only a handful of really private sites, but if you're looking to get together with families it's great. But again having only two showers for the whole park across the highway is certainly not ideal. The provincial government needs to spend some money and upgrade the facilities at this park.

name: Sturgeon Bay Provincial Park
text: Gorgeous small park.  Lovely scenery.  I was here as a child, 58 years ago.  It sure has changed...but then again  so have I.

name: Sturgeon Bay Provincial Park
text: Lovely, quiet park. The lack of comfort station is made up by the friendliness of the park wardens. Love going back there time after time.

name: Sturgeon Bay Provincial Park
text: Best Provincial Park in Ontario. Friendly staff, close access to the water from campsites, clean, and the fishing is great.

name: Sturgeon Bay Provincial Park
text:
I had a semi-relaxing weekend. The first night when we arrived there were a bunch of teenagers that were a bit loud but i guess that's expected to some degree. Other than that it was nice.

The park is small but plenty to explore if you have a boat or can drive to other parks nearby. There is a small sandy beach. The tree pollen was everywhere, so if you have bad allergies i would come here end of summer or early fall. 

The only big downfall for me was that there isn't a proper comfort station. The washrooms are where the camping is but the showers are where the cottages are - which is a drive away asccross the main road. And there are only two showers from what i saw. I would recommend to create a proper comfort station where the campers are as not everyone camps in an rv.

name: Sturgeon River Provincial Park
text: I camped out by the sturgeon river during May long weekend. It was really nice and decently fast would love to make it out for a paddle.

name: Sturgeon River Provincial Park
text: Very low water in the summer, this is not the place I recommend for white water trips in Ontario. As a through-trip to explore more of Chiniguchi or Temagami area, canoe tripping on part of the Sturgeon River is OK, but I generally avoid it in the summer.

name: The Massasauga Provincial Park
text: My favourite park! Staff is very friendly snd helpful.

name: The Massasauga Provincial Park
text: Love this park. The lake is beautiful.  There are numerous camp sites and the water is clean. You can drink it with a simple filter. Lots of wildlife, including bears. Bearboxes provided on many campsites.  All campsites water accessible only.  Canoes available for rent.

name: The Massasauga Provincial Park
text: My very favourite place to go in the summer. Fourth visit this year. Water was wonderful for swimming and paddling!

name: The Massasauga Provincial Park
text: So glad to have all the bear boxes at the sites.

name: The Massasauga Provincial Park
text: If you have your own boat or kayaks this will be a great location for you. Staffs are very warm and welcome centre is very useful

name: Tidewater Provincial Park
text: Met some friendly drug dealers while I was camping there, they had a shotgun. Cool!

name: Turkey Point Provincial Park
text: Spent a weekend here in 2018. It's a nice park but has a touristy feel to it. It's definitely a park where people go to party as it's so close to the main strip. I'd stay here again for a quick weekend but nothing more as we like the up north experience.

name: Turkey Point Provincial Park
text: The campsite was very spacious, well maintained and moderately private. We were able to see many fireflies at night. Other than the beach which was quite distant outside the park, I didn’t find many attractions or activities within the park itself. The trails were rather short, boring and often run over by mountain bikers. The beach was reasonably clean and family friendly. There was a decent sized parking lot by the beach, but the entering and finding a spot in the parking lot took a while for us during the busy season.

name: Turkey Point Provincial Park
text: Beautiful park with large sites. Close to a big beach on Lake Erie and wonderful winery's. There are local produce growers and during the summer there is a plethora of fresh things to eat.

name: Turkey Point Provincial Park
text:
Turkey Point Provincial Park and village are quaint and small village stretched along the Ontario north shore of Lake Erie one and a half hours west of Hamilton.
Great soft sandy beach, a number of restaurants and eateries and boat launches.
The village has mainly smaller cottages and the locals are friendly.
Good for children and teen friendly.

name: Turkey Point Provincial Park
text:
Turkey Point is a really fun provincial park.  The sites were well maintained and the amenities were very good.

The beach was a bit of a distance from the park itself, and you had to go into town to get to it... which, if you're camping, can be a bit of a disconnect.  But, the beach was clean and spacious, with a massive area dedicated to parking.

Full disclosure: I tend to prefer being in the woods or within the park most of the time, so when the beach is a big draw, sitting amongst store-fronts and cottages feels more like Grand Bend than camping.

name: Voyageur Provincial Park
text: It is absolutely gorgeous here! You can't go wrong to go for a a few days or a few hours. It is well kept, the beaches are always clean and beautiful! The campgrounds are all quite large with a lot of privacy. The bathrooms are always neat tidy and clean. And there is so much to do outside, enjoying nature walks, swimming, boating Etc.

name: Voyageur Provincial Park
text: Our favorite provincial park! Lots of trees and shaded/secluded sites, as well as large. Staff are great. Comfort stations always clean. We go at least once every season.

name: Voyageur Provincial Park
text: Nice open area. Lots of space, and not much light pollution. Good for camping, stargazing, retreats and weekend getaways. Toilets are acceptable and they're cleaned every day. Only downside is water doesnt taste that good. Great place overall.

name: Voyageur Provincial Park
text: Great little park that is close to Ottawa. Awesome place for a quick getaway to the outdoors when time is short, or when you just want to get away from it all. Everything is available in the nearby town of Hawkesbury.

name: Voyageur Provincial Park
text: It seems like a beautiful, park with campsites widely spaced in beautiful forest. However, we tried to stop in for lunch after searching google maps for a picnic park. It is very accessible from the highway, so we tried it. It didn't work well. You have to pay $14.50 to enter. That will be refunded if you only stay for half an hour, but it takes most of that time to get in and out to the picnic area.

name: Wabakimi Provincial Park
text: My family recently canoed through the backcountry of Wabakimi for 8 days. It was really an excellent experience with beautiful landscapes and almost pure wilderness. There is clearly very little human traffic through the park (relative to its size); we estimate that 6 of the locations we set up camp hadn't seen visitors in over a year. The portage routes are often quite tough so bring an saw/machete. Really a special experience with our two young daughters (from 6-14 years of age).

name: Wabakimi Provincial Park
text: Great family park!!We spend lots of time here.

name: Wabakimi Provincial Park
text: Lots of miles for whitewater river rafting, some areas are high class rating for ability.  Deep cultural history of this area. Remote access is available if yo like to be adventurous, but be prepared with gear.

name: Wabakimi Provincial Park
text: It is an excellent place to go and enjoy nature, the views are incredible and you can do activities such as cycling, I recommend it.

name: Wabakimi Provincial Park
text: Went fishing. Had a good time.

name: Wakami Lake Provincial Park
text: Beautiful little park. Has some beautiful sites right on the water

name: Wakami Lake Provincial Park
text: Loved this lake. So many different types of trips are possible.  Highly recommend

name: Wakami Lake Provincial Park
text: Beautiful. Website innacurate,  not updated. Well serviced. Staff are from another area. Can't answer local questions.

name: Wakami Lake Provincial Park
text: Not bad, 33$ a night. Would benefit from a shower building.

name: Wakami Lake Provincial Park
text: Awesome getaway.

name: Wasaga Beach Provincial Park
text: Loveeeee this beach 🌴During the summer, the ambiance is fantastic nice tropical music playing outside the store's and restaurants.Also, the fireworks during special events are awesome.The beach itself is clean, not too deep for the kids and the water is reasonably warm.I enjoyed each seconds playing in the sand with my little one's- it's a safe place.During the night, there is amazing bar restaurants and lounge clubs to hang out, people are just very friendly there. Approved ❤️Can't wait to go again!

name: Wasaga Beach Provincial Park
text: Great beach. Get there early to get good parking and a good spot on the beach. Lots to do for the kids:there's a bouncy castle and other little rides. Live bands are common for Saturday during the day and police do patrol often to provide added safety. Beach area 1 is the biggest and where you will find the most to do with shops, food shacks and entertainment.

name: Wasaga Beach Provincial Park
text: Clear water beach with great sand, not rocky.   One of the few beaches in Ontario that I am comfortable not wearing water shoes in the water. Stays shallow for a good distance so was perfect for my 2 1/2 year old. Very large beach and probably one of Canada's most popular beaches so if you are looking for seclusion this is not the place. Surrounded by a beach town so all the amenities are close.

name: Wasaga Beach Provincial Park
text: Awesome, the venue was fun, tons of parking and all the little stores and stops were interesting and inviting.

name: Wasaga Beach Provincial Park
text: nice long beach if willing to walk along a bit you will find a spot not too crowded. going during the week day it is less busy nice shallow water is great for young kids lots of space people are not bumping into each other. parking is expensive as is the food.

name: White Lake Provincial Park
text:
We camped here for one night on our way to Pukaskwa National Park on the first weekend of September. The park in general was very clean and quiet (probably because it was almost at the end of the season).

The campsite we used (#84) was very private and spacious, with a wooden staircase connecting to a small beach at the back. The campsite next door (#86) was even more private and spacious, but the entrance was too muddy for our car at the time.
In the evening, we could hear songs from the Pic Mobert First Nation across the lake. For us, it wasn’t bothering at all. We somewhat enjoyed hearing them. 
There were very loud train horns twice in the morning, but we didn’t really care since we were up and leaving early anyways.

I did not have much time to try fishing – only managed to cast few times from the shore and caught nothing. Nevertheless, I heard fishing is usually fantastic here. I briefly checked out the docks and fish cleaning stations, and they seemed pretty neat, too.

The shower facility was one of the cleanest I have ever seen in Provincial Parks.
The park staff member at the gatehouse was very friendly as well.

name: White Lake Provincial Park
text: Huge sites, pretty private, close off the highway for a quick stay like ours. Heard the train horn just after 8am on a Sunday which was no biggie for us as we were up. Other than that it is very quiet here. Wish we could have had full hook ups but this is to be expected at a provincial park. Big play ground and a decent beach. Boil water advisory. Current fire ban on.

name: White Lake Provincial Park
text: Nice area to camp in. Super shower facilities. Only stayed one night so wasn't able to do more than hike a little. They do offer small watercraft, boats like canoes and kayaks to rent.

name: White Lake Provincial Park
text: Nice place to spend a night on the way somewhere else

name: White Lake Provincial Park
text: Very pleasant, beautiful lush woods, with modest beaches great to stargaze from. Wow, did it ever get damp & cold in some evenings though. We were there in early August. Some of the more seasoned campers/fishermen had elaborate, yet clearly effective camping setups.

name: Windy Lake Provincial Park
text: Awesome day on the trails today.

name: Windy Lake Provincial Park
text: My weekend hideout!   Staff is awesome. Beach is rough on the feet but kids dont care and plenty of space.  Love it!!

name: Windy Lake Provincial Park
text: Great experience nice, friendly campers no excessive noise only downside is the train tracks right beside the park

name: Windy Lake Provincial Park
text: A favourite park.  But the beach is so far fro. Campground.... need to drive to beach.  Also hope you like trains at night.

name: Windy Lake Provincial Park
text: Great place, but Trains in the night ruin all the  fun. Expect 2-3 trains every night. They come, they honk, they leave. They come, they honk they leave.

name: Woodland Caribou Provincial Park
text: Carroll lake lodge is an amazing place to stay for fishing.  Best of service.

name: Woodland Caribou Provincial Park
text: Favourite place. Go to Sabourin Lake Lodge.

name: Woodland Caribou Provincial Park
text: I have been a long time Quetico trekker-this Park is incomparable! Fabulous fishing, well maintained portages without the technical aspects of the Quetico, great campsites and a great outfitter (Red Lake Outfitters) who actually goes into the park. I have visited the BWCA and Quetico for over 50 years and I was WOWED!

name: Woodland Caribou Provincial Park
text: Beautiful area, can't wait to go back

name: Woodland Caribou Provincial Park
text: Beautiful.
